head_text.subj: INT. TIBETAN PEASANT HOME, KITCHEN DAWN, (1937)

text: The MOTHER walks past the boy, her woolen skirt swaying i the rosy light.  A seven year-old brother - LOBSANG SAMTE and a teenage sister - TSERING DOLMA - share Lhamo's kitc mattress.  Lhamo looks at them, and then he turns to see heavy felt boots of his FATHER, as the man walks through room and out the door.  Lhamo finds the kind face of his MOTHER.  She is looking at him.

The boy walks across the stone courtyard as we hear the sounds of this country morning:  the snorting of horses, clucking of hens, a command from the Father as the man fe the animals. The boy scratches, he pees.  He sees his Mother on the ro She is a silhouette against the dawn, as she feeds cedar yak chips into the incense burner - sending white, curly smoke up, to circle the prayer flag and its clusters of printed mantras. We pull back as the spotted dog begins to bark. Lhamo's house is the house in the vision.
It is a good day.  There is cheese for breakfast. Lhamo's Father sits on a cushion at the head of a low tab Fresh bread appears, yogurt, roasted barley (tsampa). Lhamo pushes at his Father.
Me.
No.  This must stop.
Me.  Here.
I am the father.  You sit there.
Me here.
What is the harm?
He will grow up all wrong. Only you can serve him, only you can wash his bowl. Too tidy, everything just so. He must know his place.
He thinks he is king here. No respect.
What is the harm?
The Father reluctantly gets up and gives his seat to Lham Lhamo settles and waits for his Mother to hand him his bo of tsampa.  He bestows a most beautiful smile on his fami

The Father is leaving the yard with a short string of hor when there is a sudden commotion. The CHINESE GOVERNOR is passing through this little villa He is a ferocious looking man, dressed in ornate brocade, his horse eguipped with tack that looks like armor.  He i surrounded by a dozen Chinese soldiers, all on huge horse ruling the road, kicking up mud. Lhamo's Father stops.  He holds still.  He looks to the house. The Mother is holding the children against her in the doorway.  Quiet.  Watching. The Governor and his entourage move on.  When they are ou of sight, Lhamo's Father makes his departure.
Lhamo straddles the window sill, slapping his bottom as i he were a horse, shouting:
I go away. Look, mama, I go away. Far, far, far.
His Mother is making bread in the kitchen.
Oh, no.  Where will he go?
Far, far away.
Lhamo is playing a game with pebbles on the raised, woode platform in the kitchen.  The fire is lit.  He is alone. The dog begins to bark.
Good day.
Good day.
Please, come in, so cold.
We are traveling to Lhasa.  May we...?
Of course, please, this way. Your servant may use the kitchen.
Thank you.

A middle-aged man, the SERVANT, wearing heavy, ragged clothes and wrapped boots, enters the kitchen. Lhamo slides over so that the man can sit on the platform beside him.  The man picks up a few pebbles and drops the he knows the game. We recognize this servant.  His name is KEUSTANG RINPOCHE He is one of the monks we saw at the Oracle lake, the one with the mesmerizing eyes.  Keustang Rinpoche is the Lama Sera Monastery. Lhamo sees a dark brown rosary around the Servant's neck immediately pulls at the string of beads.
Mine.
The Servant takes the rosary off and gives it to the boy. Lhamo hangs the string of beads around his own neck.  The Servant makes a move to take back the rosary, but Lhamo resists.
Mine.
Mine.
Please.
I will give it to, if you can tell me who I am.
Lhamo looks up, into the man's piercing, black eyes.
The Lama of Sera. You come.
The Mother enters and immediately sees the rosary around son's neck.  She gives it back to the Servant.
Lhamo, no.
Lhamo goes back to his game.  The Mother hands the tired a slice of bread and a steaming cup of tea.  The man's hands are shaking.  He cannot look the woman in the eye.
Thank you.
The travelers make their departure at dawn. As the party reaches the gate, Lhamo runs from the house, crying:
Wait!  No!
The men stop.  Lhamo runs to the Servant.
Me, too.  Me go, too. Lhasa!
Lhamo is in tears.
No, no, no.  Lhasa! He always says he will travel far away.  He always wants to go.
We cannot, young master.
You come back?
A pause.
We will.
The travelers head down the road. Mother and child return to their home, the Mother carryin the boy on her hip as he swings himself around to take a last look at the strangers.
The Father readies a pack train of horses.  Lobsang and Lhamo pull on the cinche straps.
The Mother plows with a heavy yoke attached to a large ya Lobsang Samten and Tsering Dolma help their mother.  Lham sleeps under an umbrella.
Lobsang and Lhamo running, carrying a bowl of eggs.
Lobsang is wrapped in maroon wool, trying to hold still a his Mother pins and stitches.  Lhamo sits, sipping tea, watching, woefully.
Say, Kumbum Monastery.
Kumbum. It is not far away.
It is not far at all, and it is a beautiful place. And your big brother is abbott there. You will not be alone.
I will be very smart.
You will be fine. You will be a fine monk.

Lobsang pours water from one small, copper bowl into six others, seven in all, placed on an altar before a statue Buddha.  As the rest of the family watches, the Mother lights the butter lamps, whispering:
Om mani padme hum. Om mani padme hum.
Lobsang is perched on the back of a horse - in front of h Father.  The two leave home, goodbyes having already been said.  Mother, sister and little brother remain behind.
Mother lies down with Lhamo, holding him.
Your father had been very sick. He had been sick from the time you began growing in me. We thought he would die.
Cow.
Yes.  A cow had died. One night, you stopped all your moving, and I said to your sister, "His time has come."
Me.  First break of day.
At dawn, you were born. One eye was closed, and your sister opened it with her thumb.  We gave you the sweet drink.
I pooped.
His Mother laughs.
You did.  We washed you and wrapped you in sheepskin and took you to your father.  That day he father got better And that day, a pair of crows came to nest in our roof.  I just remembered.
I miss my brother.
I miss him too.
CLOSE on the Mother as she holds Lhamo, now her only son home. A view of Kyeri mountain turning from a pre-dawn purple t light pink in the sunlight.
The multi-colored prayer flags flap in the wind as the co crows and the animals come awake.  Father exits the house and begins his day.

head_text.subj: EXT. SIDE OF THE HOUSE DAY

text: Lhamo is watching two bugs fighting when he hears the dog bark.  He climbs the low, stone wall and looks out at the road. Six TRAVELERS approach.  Four of the men are dressed as nobility, wearing red and gold silk.  Two men are monks. The Mother meets the men in the courtyard. A monk steps forward.  He bows.
I am the Lama of Sera.
Sera Monastery?  From Lhasa?
Yes.  We have business here.
Lhamo jumps off the wall.  He carefully lifts the smaller beetle from the path of the larger beetle.  He places the rescued bug safely in a clump of grass.

CLOSE on the faces of the six men. CLOSE on the small face of Lhamo as he looks down at the bed. Lying on a piece of yellow silk are many objects.  There three of each type of object:  three walking sticks, thre drums, three silver pens, three eating bowls, three bells three rosaries, three pairs of spectacles. The Lama of Sera - Keustang Rinpoche - hands Lhamo the rosary he had so coveted when the man first visited.
This is yours, you say. What else belongs to you?

Lhamo considers the request, then climbs onto the bed to study the objects.  The drum and the bell he chooses quickly. Keustang Rinpoche watches the boy gather the items.  He looks at the yellow silk and the boy's small, fine hands. He dares not look directly at the boy. Lhamo picks up one walking stick - a lovely, bronze-handl one.  He swings it around, but he finally rejects it in favor of a plain, iron-handled stick.  He makes his own p of these things, then looks at the Lama of Sera.
Yes, those are yours.
Keustang Rinpoche takes the boy's hands in his own.  He turns them over, examines them.
With permission?

The Lama carefully pulls back the boy's overalls.  There a little birthmark, like a conch shell, on his shoulder. Keustang Rinpoche pulls up the boy's pants legs.  There i funny skin marking on the legs, like tiger stripes. The Lama rearranges the boy's clothing, then one more tim takes the beautiful, little hands in his own and whispers
"Kundun"
He says to the others, in a soft, secretive voice:
He is the Presence.
In the background, by an open curtain, we see Lhamo's Mother. She says, softly:
My oldest boy is an incarnation.
So is your youngest.
Keustang releases the boy's hands and brings his own clos palms up to his forehead.
I wish you long life.
The Mother begins to cry.

Little Lhamo, now dressed in yellow, fills the copper wat bowls with difficulty. His parents stand beside him.  They share one, frightened curious look. CLOSE on the statue of Buddha.  It is an image of Chenrez the Buddha of Compassion.  He has eleven heads and four, outstretched arms.
Lhamo sits in the saddle in front of his Mother.  His Fat and Sister ride beside them, through an incredible, empty Tibetan landscape.  A Monk rides lead.
Turquoise-roof, golden-pagoda, a beautiful, white-washed monastery built against a terraced, green hillside of Amd

Mother pats her son Lhamo's unruly hair and makes a soft, comforting sound.  Lobsang is there beside his brother. Lobsang is already dressed as a tiny monk - in a maroon robe, with short, clipped hair  An older brother, TAKSTER age 17, a lama, is there. The Mother lies:
I will be back in a few days.
How many?
Two.
Lhamo holds up two fingers.
This many?
Yes, yes.  Your brothers are here.
Takster moves closer.  She places the sad youngster in Takster's arms.
One more kiss.

Lhamo kisses her, as does Lobsang and even Takster falls into her arms for a moment.  Then, she turns and goes, quickly. A Monk appears.  He produces a concertina and begins to p for the little boy. But, Lhamo begins to cry, through the music, through the hugs of his brothers.  As a result of Lhamo's tears, Lobs begins to cry.  Takster holds them both.  The music continues. The older, wiser, Takster begins to cry, too. The three brothers hold one another.  Three brothers, thr monks, crying for their mother.  The music continues, echoing in this stone monastery. The young "Kundun" is gently rocked by his older brother. He begins to fall asleep.

The sound of the concertina becomes chanting and we see r after row of monks, in a temple, their voices mingling in the empty room. View of a courtyard, with young novices, reciting.  Lobsa is among them.
"May I be the doctor and the medicine, And may I be the nurse, For all sick beings in the world, until everyone is healed."

A TEACHER, a very stern-looking monk, carrying a thick, f board, menacingly, behind his back, walks among the students. A golden head of a Buddha - a huge head - appears to be bursting through an archway at the end of a dark hallway. The Chinese Governor stands, like a giant, against the bl sky.  Omnipotent.  Frightening.
I want him accompanied by my Chinese soldiers.
Keustang Rinpoche, also a head against blue sky, argues:
This is Tibet. We are not under your authority.
CLOSE on the Chinese Governor.
I want one hundred thousand Chinese dollars, if you want the boy.
CLOSE on Keustang Rinpoche.  Slowly, he nods. An image of the Father and the Mother, standing in their courtyard, staring at the departing search party. The Mother asks over and over:
But why?  Who is Lhamo? Who do they say he is?
Her husband does not know. View of the Mother, on the roof, feeding cedar and yak ch into the incense burner.  We hear: BOYS (reciting) "May I be protector for those without one."
Lhamo wakes up.  He is in a brilliant, green room.

head_text.subj: INT. STUDY ROOM, KUMBUM MONASTERY DAY

text: The stern-looking Teacher from his dream is there, readin scripture, reciting:
"May I be a bridge, a boat, a ship For all who wish to cross the water."
Lhamo looks down at the complicated words.
Can you recite?

The boy just waits, sad, lonely. The Teacher offers Lhamo an apricot.  Lhamo takes the fru The Monk pats the boy's head, gently, and Lhamo takes shelter in the kind man's massive robes.  The view become sunlight through deep, maroon wool.

thamo and Lobsang  sit inside a idreljam" - a rough palanquin, which is attached to two poles and carried between two mules.  The vehicle rises and falls, pitches twists as it is carried along the roadless, Tibetan plain Lhamo reaches forward and pulls back a curtain.

The boy is traveling with a caravan.  It is not, in fact, enormous caravan, maybe fifty people, including:  Lhamo's family, members of the search party, monks, Muslim trader The dreljam DRIVER looks over at Lhamo and signals that t boy should close the curtain. Lhamo does so, only to lean across his brother to look ou the other side of his tiny carriage. The other side opens to a view of the great, empty land. herd of deer grazes beside the travelers.  Mountains rise the distance.  A flock of geese flies overhead. Lhamo closes the curtain.
Lhamo elbows his brother.  Lobsang elbows him back.  The begin to squabble.
You have all the room.
Don't be a baby, move over.
You move.
You!  You think you are so big!

They hit and pinch until finally the movement of the carriage stops.  The Driver reaches in through the open curtains and separates the boys, each to his own side of dreljam. Inside his tiny carriage, young Lhamo now sits quiet and composed.
A cluster of fantastic, Tibetan tents are set up; white cotton tents, with sharp corners, peaked ceilings and elaborate, appliqued designs.  Campfires glow, animals be down, stars shine overhead.
CLOSE on a group of ancient, stern-faced MONKS. CLOSE on the baby-faced, Lhamo Dhondrup. One Monk pulls a huge pair of scissors from his robes. Lhamo makes a dive for the tent's door.

Standing outside the tent is a BODYGUARD - a huge, burly man, wearing monk's robes.  He turns to the boy.  In one hand he holds a big stick.  His face is distorted and deformed by a large tumor under one eye.  It is a frightening sight.  He looks like a monster to the child. Lhamo jumps back inside the tent.  The Bodyguard closes t appliqued flap.
Lhamo has had a haircut.  His Mother walks beside the carriage, holding his hand.
Who am I?
We do not know.
By candlelight, Lhamo is transferred from the rugged, sim carriage, to one of exquisite, yellow silk.
Lhamo peeks out of the silk curtain as he hears the arriv of many horses, many men.  SOLDIERS - hundreds of Tibetan soldiers - surround the palanquin.

The yellow palanquin is carried across a human border of Tibetan noblemen.  These fantastic-looking men and women part, and drop to the ground in prostration, as the palanquin moves through their welcoming committee.

Lhamo walks along a long, patterned carpet, looking up, a this lofty tent's stunning, blue silk, ceiling. He is led to a tall, wooden throne, and he is lifted, and then he climbs to the top.  Lhamo settles in a cross-legg position on the brocade cushion. He looks down. Hundred of monks, abbots, noblemen, Nepalese, Bhutanese, Chinese, even a red-headed Englishman - they all bow to Lhamo. Reting Rinpoche, the young Regent of Tibet, the man who s this boy's face in his vision, stands below the throne. addresses the crowd:
Chenrezi, the Buddha of compassion. The Wish Fulfilling Jewel. The Fourteenth Dalai Lama.
And the Regent turns, hikes up his gorgeous robes, and prostrates before the child.
Long life.

In the crowd stand Lhamo's Mother and Father and Lobsang Samten. On their faces, we must see that they did not realize who their son, their brother, was believed to be. First the Mother, and then the Father, bow in front of th youngest child.
Long life.
Long life.
Finally, Lobsang.
Long life, Lhamo.
We hear the sound of a great, Tibetan horn. We hear peels of childish laughter.

Lobsang and Lhamo skid, slide, skate down the endless, slippery hallways of this huge, labyrinthine monastery. Three Monks scurry behind the boys, trying to keep up, trying to keep the young incarnate from slipping out of their sight. They shout, in loud stage whispers:
Kundun!  Kundun!
The monks are no match for the little boys, who are quick out of sight.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS THE POTALA DAY

text: Reting Rinpoche sits cross-legged on the floor of this brightly-painted, red room. Across from him sits Lhamo, dressed in fine, yellow silk. These are simple rooms, decorated with statues, deity scrolls and mandalas, an altar to Buddha.  Behind a glass case are toys, mixed in with the Buddhist artifacts:  dol puppets, balls, blocks, trains. Reting Rinpoche is speaking.

Centuries ago, a young boy was born.  His name was Gedundrub. The night of his birth, robbers came to his home and his family fled hiding the baby in a cattle pen. When they returned the next day, the baby was safe. They found him guarded by a pair of black crows. He was the first Dalai Lama. The Living Buddha of Compassion. Now, you have chosen to come back to this life once again.
Reting blows his nose.
We name you Tenzin Gyatso.
CLOSE on Lhamo - Tenzin Gyatso.

Your job is simple. You are to love all living things. Just love them.  Care for them. Have compassion for them. "As long as any living thing draws breath, wherever he shall be, there in compassion, shall the Buddha appear, incarnate."
At the curtain behind Lhamo, we notice the curly-toed sho of a monk, a man who must be standing in the next room.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS DAY

text: In the room immediately adjacent to this bedroom, we now the three Monks who chased the young boy down the slipper halls. They are the Dalai Lama's personal attendants - the MASTE OF THE RITUAL, the MASTER OF ThE KITCHEN, and the MASTER THE ROBE.  (It is the Master of the Kitchen who stands directly behind the curtain.) The LORD CHAMBERLAIN is also there.  He is a monk.  A tal angular man, with almost nordic features:  large, round eyes, a yellowish mustache, sharp nose. All of these men will become quite familiar to us, as wil the man standing, listening, behind the attendants. He is a sweeper, a man named NORBU THUNDRUP, age thirty. is tall, and gangly, with a wispy beard and a pock-marked face.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOM DAY

text: You will be the leader of the Tibetan people when you come of age.  Until that time, I will be your teacher, and as your Regent, I will rule in your name. I will tell your Lord Chamberlain you are ready to see him.
The Regent walks through this room on his way out. A passing look from Norbu lets us know that Reting Rinpoche is not well-liked.
He will see you now.
The Lord Chamberlain goes to meet with the Dalai Lama.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOM DAY

text: The Lord Chamberlain bows to the boy and then unpacks his parcel. He has a rolled, parchment document. He has a beautiful, carved, wooden box. The Lord Chamberlain points to the mural on the wall behi the boy.  It is an elaborate, story-painting.
Fifth Dalai Lama.
The boy looks. The Lord Chamberlain points to a golden statue of a round man in a peaked hat.
Seventh Dalai Lama.
Tenzin Gyatso nods. The Lord Chamberlain lifts a framed photograph of a bald, charismatic man, with razor sharp eyebrows, pictured sitt on a throne.
Thirteenth Dalai Lama.

The boy looks at the photo. The Lord Chamberlain places the state seal in the young boy's hands and indicates that the boy should bring the heavy instrument down hard on the parchment. The boy does.  The Lord Chamberlain scribbles a little something on a tab of attached paper, then bows to the bo
Fourteenth Dalai Lama.
Outside, up a country path, young herders lead their catt in from the grazing fields.  We can hear the boys singing a Tibetan street song.
I am the good one. You be bad. The bad man.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOM DUSK

text: The view comes in the window and reveals the young Dalai Lama, sitting on the floor with Norbu Thundrup, the sweep Tenzin Gyatso has arranged a battlefield of soldiers - little men, made of colored-dough.
My name is Norbu, Holiness.  I will be good, you be bad.
Tenzin Gyatso is ferocious in his strategy, taking Norbu' men.

I'm on a big mountain and hitting at the bad men. And after the game, we're going to trade.  You just stay over there, no, there!, Norbu, and I will shoot at you. I want your land.  I take it. I am stronger.
I am braver.
Norbu Thundrup plays like a child.  It is a fight to the finish.
I have more men. NORBU ThUNDRUP I have smarter men.
Tenzin Gyatso has lost;  he dissolves into tears.
Today you lose.  Tomorrow you may win.
Norbu snaps his fingers.
Things change, Kundun.
Why is your beard so funny? Let me touch this.
Tenzin touches the soft, bald, chin of Norbu.
Soft.
And then, Tenzin Gyatso tries to snap his fingers.  He cannot.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS DUSK

text: Tenzin Gyatso stands at the window, watching, listening. His hands knead the colored dough into balls, ready to create the next army, the future battleground, as he recites, softly:
"As long as all living draw breaths, there Buddha is."
Norbu Thundrup smiles as he polishes the floor, clearing of tsampa dough.

head_text.subj: INT. GREAT HALL, THE POTALA DAY

text: The Great Hall in the Potala is the seat of Tibetan Government. These palace walls are hung with beautiful, old thangkas (silk embroideries or paintings),  depicting the life of Buddha. Inside the hall sits the acting government:  the YIGSTANG and the TSITANG - four monks, four laymen - all dressed i their appropriate simplicity and elaborateness.  These me sit in two rows, facing one another.  The senior monk and the senior layman sit a bit forward. They are the speaker The senior LAYMAN is on his knees, speaking.
I believe that the Regent is asking for too high a reward for his part in finding the Dalai Lama.  Too much money, too much land.
Tenzin Gyatso peeks through a door at the great assembly. The Lord Chamberlian stands behind him.
The Layman continues.
Our treasuries are empty.  Our army is depleted.  He would have us pull the hair from our noses.
The Dalai Lama is confused, but continues listening.
The Layman returns to his cross-legged position. The senior MONK speaks.
We note this.  Now, the Chinese.
There is audible expression of tension.
The Allies wish to build a supply- road from India, crossing Tibet, as part of their war effort.  The road would lead directly to China.
The Layman gets to his knees.

We cannot allow it. Right now, we have a only a small Chinese mission in Lhasa, the first since the Thirteenth Dalai Lama threw them out in 1912. The road would increase the size of that mission. The Chinese would try to control our trade, as they did once before, control our contact with the outside world.

The Lord Chamberlain touches the boy's shoulder and Tenzi Gyatso leaves his hiding place, as the speaker's voice fa away. As the two walk down the hallway, Tenzin Gyatso spots an unusual wooden door.  He lets the Lord Chamberlain get a little bit ahead of him, and then the boy tries the door. It is heavy.  It almost opens.
Tenzin Gyatso and his brother Lobsang are pulling at the heavy door.  Behind them, in the distance, we hear:
Kundun!  Kundun!
The door opens.  The boys disappear inside.

A treasure awaits them. It looks like Aladdin's cave - full of odd, European item There are glittering music boxes, a porcelain sink, a gil mirror, a lacquered rocking horse.  There are hats, umbrellas and even a pair of lace-up, cordovan shoes. Tenzin Gyatso lifts a reel of film.  There are piles of magazines and books.  There is a stack of tires in the ba corner.  The boys uncover a train set and a good collecti of lead soldiers.  The Dalai Lama pockets a gold watch. Just as the monks find their young charges and we hear th at the door, Tenzin sees something truly spectacular.  It a telescope. The monks enter the room as the young Dalai Lama reaches this miracle.
What is it?
Ah, it is a telescope, Holiness. With this you can see a long way.
And, is it mine?
These are all gifts sent to your predecessors.
Yes!  Then it is yours!
I need it.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS NIGHT

text: We are in the adjacent room, listening, as Norbu Thundrup tells a bedtime story. Golden butter lamps burn before a statue of Buddha.
One night, not too long ago, an old monk saw a woman in that very same hallway where you ran away.
The boy is in bed.  The Sweeper finishes-off his story as the boy wiggles deeper under the covers.
She carried a basket in her arms, a big, heavy basket, and the old monk cautiously approached. She opened her basket and showed what she had.  Heads.  Human heads. Only the heads.
Is that true or pretend?
It is a story, you decide.
Pretend.
As you say.

The Sweeper tucks the boy in as the Master of the Robe finishes his nightly preparations and with a pat and a smile, the two men leave the room. A mouse steals a bit of tsampa from the offerings placed the altar before the Buddha. Tenzin Gyatso peeks out from under his covers and looks t see if those curly-toed shoes are visible under the partition.  They are.  The Master of the Kitchen is still near. Tenzin Gyatso pulls the golden pocket watch from under th covers.  He pries and digs at the back of the watch until succeeds in popping it open, revealing its miraculous insides. Finally, Tenzin Gyatso's eyelids grow heavy.  The camera passes over his face, as his eyes close. The boy begins to speak, mumble, as he falls asleep:
"I be an island for those who seek one, a lamp for light."

We find two scrolls;  the first is PENDEN LHAMO, the spec protectress of the Dalai Lama. She rides her wild mule through a sea of blood - between rows of jagged mountains.  Pointed fingers and spreading toes, her hair gone crazy, her fangs revealed - the detai are incredible.  A garland of freshly severed heads hangs around her body, snakes hold up her skirt, five skulls fo ber crown.
"May I be a bed for all who wish to rest, and a slave for all who want a slave."

Beside her, on the second scroll is MAHAKALA.  He is the fierce representation of the Buddha of Compassion.  Crows fly in the clouds to the left of the terrifying, black, s armed figure. A skull rosary is held in the upper right arm, a Trident held in the left hand.  The deity wears a crown of five skulls.  He has three eyes.  He tramples an elephant. We might have been in a dream, as the camera finally move back to find the peaceful1 protected face of the young Da Lama.  Asleep. The camera moves across the mural devoted to the story of the Fifth Dalai Lama.  It is a fantasy of green, with mountains and lakes and deities and monsters. We find the statue of Seventh Dalai Lama, sitting on his golden cushion, and we look, deep into the eyes of the Thirteenth Dalai Lama.  Fantastic.  Deeper.  Deeper.
"May I be wishing jewel, a magic vase...
We see the Dalai Lama place his young eye at the viewfind

Norbu Thundrup holds the boy steady. And, a wondorous view of Lhasa is presented. Vendors hawk their goods to elegant ladies, wearing turquoise jewelry and carrying silken parasols.  Animals herded through town by young boys.  Children play and squabble.  A white wall is covered with cartoons, lampoon political posters - picturing the Regent, perhaps, as a m holding too much power.
I want to go down there.
You can only go with attendants and a big ceremony.
I want to run down the street. I want to buy a toy.  Eat from the shops.
You cannot.
I want to be a shepherd, taking those goats and cows out to the hillside.
But you are not a shepherd, you are the Dalai Lama.
Maybe in the next life, the world will not need a Dalai Lama. NORNU ThUNDRUP I would not know.  Maybe.

The view travels and we see a prison yard.  Shackled men share the yard with hairy, fat dogs. One man looks up and sees that the yard is under surveillance.  Of course the men all know that this terra belongs to the boy Dalai Lama. As the boy watches, first one poor, ragged man, then anot prostrates. Tenzin Gyatso pulls away from the telescope.  He waves to the prisoners.

The boy rides in his palanquin of yellow silk. He is older now, seven or eight.  He peers through the curtain. A grand procession carries the Dalai Lama from the Potala his summer residence, the Norbulinka. Monks walk in procession, as do members of the aristocrac wearing their finest gowns and jewelry, holding their fin parasols, and soldiers, wearing ancient uniforms.  There horses, banners and carriages.  Bodyguards carry the Dala Lama's possessions - wrapped in yellow silk.  A band play "God Save the King." It is a magnificent display, and along the side of the ro Tibetans prostrate in the presence of the boy, not daring look at him.

Establishing shot of this lovely park. Zt looks like a sweet, summer home compared to the loomin expansiveness of the Potala.  It is filled with deer and antelope, peacocks and nesting birds.  An eccentric collection of trees grow here - some indigenous, some gifts - bearing flowers and fruit.  There are fish ponds even a Kyichu river tributary nearby. We find the young Dalai Lama standing by this tributary daring to put one foot on a slippery, stepping stone.  An Attendant gently pulls him back. Beyond the river, a herder leads a small group of braying sheep towards town.  The boy watches.  He listens to the herder's song.
The Dalai Lama drops bits of food into a fish pond.  He calls the huge, lazy fish to come eat.
Little ones first, only little ones.
The boy pushes the bigger ones away with a stick.

Tenzin Gyatso runs through an open gate in a mustard yell wall (which separates the Dalai Lama's residence from the rest of the Norbulinka), and up the steps leading to a white, one story, home - his parent's.

A startling, blue room. The young Dalai Lama leans on the table where is Father s eating pork rinds. Lobsang is there, practicing his writing on a chalk board Tenzin Gyatso grabs one pork rind, then another, then a third.
The Dalai Lama is not supposed to eat pork.  It is not good for your brain.

The Father uses the grease from the roasted lamb on the table to caress his long mustache and twirl each side int point. The Dalai Lama takes another, and then, suddenly, the boy reaches up and for no reason, he pulls on his Father's mustache, obviously hurting the man.  The Father slaps th boy's hand, hard. The boy sits back, and begins drawing imaginary letters o the tabletop with his slapped hand. His Father reaches out and takes the hurt hand.  He pulls the boy into his arms.
I am sorry, Lhamo.
It is alright, Father.
The Master of the Robe knocks at the door.  Father and so look up.
Kundun, you must come back now.
The young boy sits straight up on his Father's lap and sa defiantly:
Go away.
The surprised Monk backs away from the door.
Not the way to talk to people.
Can I do anything I want?
No.
But, I am in charge.
Are you?  Of whom?
The boy thinks.
Can I save the sheep from going to the market?  So they don't die.
You could buy them.
Do I have money?
What do you think?
Do you have money?
I do, now.
And you have horses? You love horses.
I do, beautiful horses. Thank you, Holiness.
Will you buy the sheep for me?
Where will you keep them?
Here.  We'll collect them.
I will buy them for you.
Can I free the prisoners?
Hmmm.
You can't do anything real until you are Dalai Lama.
I am him.
Not until you are eighteen.
You have escaped once more.

The Mother has been in the doorway, listening. Tenzin Gyatso disengages from his Father's arms and goes his Mother.  Tenzin reaches into one of her large, apron pockets and finds nothing.  Another.  Nothing.  He reache into her sash and pulls out a special-looking sweet.  She takes the boy's hand and leads him from the house.
Go study.  I get in trouble if you do not study.
Lobsang looks at his Father.
I do.
Sometimes you strike the goat, to scare the sheep.
I am the goat. He is a naughty sheep.
He will not be ours much longer.
CLOSE on the Father's face.
The Mother walks the boy back to his residence, through t gate in the yellow wall.
I have news.  The Regent has resigned his post.
Is he a bad man?  Norbu says he is "lavish" and "willful". "How can he give you monk's vows if he has not kept them himself?"
Well, some say. It's not for you to worry about. Another will be chosen.
He was always nice to me. He found me.  He saw me in his dreams.

head_text.subj: EXT. DALAI LAMA'S RESIDENCE, NORBULINKA DAY

text: They have reached the residence.  The boy's Mother caress his little head.
I turn you over again, today, Lhamo.  One day, you will not be able to come running to us.
But you will always be here?
Me?
You will always!
I have one more piece of news.  A baby is coming.
Tenzin grabs at her stomach and shrieks with laughter.
Oh, Mama!  Who will it be?
The Mother places her hands on Tenzin Gyatso's.
Oh, no!  Who can it be?
A string of old monks, stand, waiting for the naughty boy

location: ENTRANCE HALL, DALAI LAMA'S RESIDENCE, NORBULINKA,

text: The boy runs up the stairs and towards the old men, but h stops and looks at a small cabinet standing, unobtrusivel in a corner.  Tenzin Gyatso goes to the cabinet and rattl the locked door.
My teeth!  My teeth are in here!
A monk takes the boy by the hand and leads him down a hallway.
My old teeth!

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, EVENING

text: A bell and a dorge are laid out on a small table.  Tenzin Gyatso sits in front of this table. A monk is chanting in low, deep tones, in the background. The Dalai Lama's teacher, TAKTRA RINPOCHE, sits on the floor.  (Being the teacher, Taktra Rinpoche sits slightly higher than the Dalai Lama.)  Taktra is an older man, in sixties.  He is stern, solid, no-nonsense. Taktra Rinpoche begins a prayer.
"I take refuge in the three jewels, The Buddha, the Dharma and the Sangra."
But the boy leaps up from his table and goes to Taktra an hangs around his neck, shouting:
You recite! You recite!
Taktra gives the boy just the slightest of looks.
"I take refuge in the three jewels, The Buddha, the Dharma and the Sangra."
Tenzin Gyatso releases the Lama and goes back to his own table.
"Until I attain enlightenment."

Taktra Rinpoche has a small table with the same hand instruments in front of him.  The teacher lifts the dorge in a particular fashion, and rotates it. Tenzin Gyatso lifts his dorge.  Taktra's hands move to th boy's and show him the correct movement.  It is tried aga Now, the bell is lifted and rung.
I would like you to be my new Regent.

Taktra stops.  He nods to the boy. As the chanting continues, Taktra Rinpoche begins a weavi motion with his hands, delicate, beautiful, hypnotic. Tenzin Gyatso copies the elder. We are CLOSE on the boy's moving hands. The chanting beco the voices of a hundred men, as we FADE OUT. FADE IN:  on the boy's hands, but they are a little large they are the hands of an eleven or twelve year-old boy - the motion they carry out is on the verge of becoming extraordinarily beautiful.

Tenzin Gyatso sits alone, in a small, dark green, room. is older.  His robes have changed slightly, his manner is more refined, more dignified. He is on a retreat. There is a soft knock at the door.  The door is opened an food is placed inside the small room by bodiless hands. Tenzin Gyatso collects his food.  He sips his tea and eat his tsampa, while reading from a long, narrow stack of scriptures.  Thangkas of MILERAPA - the great Tibetan poe and teacher - hang on the walls. We notice the curly-toed shoes of the Master of the Kitch just visible beneath the wooden door.

The boy walks alone, moving to the rhythm of a memorizati His breath consolidates in the cold night air.  The sky i brilliant with stars. TENZIN GYATSO (reciting) "As long as any living thing draws breath, wherever he shall be, there, in compassion, shall the Buddha appear, incarnate."

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, THE POTALA DAY

text: School is in session. LING RINPOCHE is teaching.  Ling is a young, shy, brillia monk, with a very round face.  He is now senior tutor.
The Four Noble Truths.
Tenzin Gyatso, sitting cross legged on a cushion, respond

The Four Noble Truths, as taught by the Lord Sakyamuni Buddha are: The Truth of Suffering The Truth of the Cause of Suffering, The Truth of the Cessation of Suffering, the Truth of the Way which leads to the cessation of Suffering.
I accept it. What is suffering?
True suffering arises from contaminated actions and afflictions.  Birth, illness, grief, old age, poverty, pain, death - these are surferings.
I accept it. What are the causes of suffering?
The causes of suffering arise from true sources.  Attachment, desire, envy, hatred, greed, unkindness, wrong view and so forth - these are some causes of suffering.

Now we CUT BACK to Ling Rinpoche, but he is standing, outside, in a courtyard.  He asks another question, but h raises his right hand as he speaks, and lowers his left, completing the question with a clap of the hands.

It is a beautiful, blue-sky day.  The Dalai Lama is learn "debate".  High Lamas sit on tapestry pillows, under appliqued canopies, observing.  Young monks can be seen, watching, from a greater distance. The Lord Chamberlain sits to one side.  Taktra Rinpoche, Regent, is beside him. The Dalai Lama sits on the ground at Ling's feet.
How does one progress from the realization of one Noble Truth to another? (clap)
A long silence from His Holiness.  The Lamas wait on tend hooks.  Finally, the boy says:
We will have to think about that.
There is laughter.  Even Ling Rinpoche laughs and the boy erupts into his beautiful, free, easy laugh.
I need to squeeze this brain.
Answer. (clap)
A pause, and then:

When one understands that he causes some of his own suffering, needlessly, then he looks for the causes in his own life. And when and he looks for those causes, when he investigates, then he is putting confidence in his own ability to eliminate the sources and end the suffering. A wish to find a path to peace arises. For all beings desire happiness.  All wish to find their purest selves.
Ling nods in approval. He looks to the elders.
I accept it.
Taktra Rinpoche and the Lord Chamberlain are proud.

Tenzin Gyatso runs up a slant board and leaps off the edg a big jump, a flying leap.  He falls to the ground, then gets up, laughing, and runs up the board again. The same old monks who watched him debate, watch him play The Lord Chamberlain and Taktra Rinpoche are among them. The Lord Chamberlain obviously loves watching his young charge play.  The Regent is not so sure.
Careful!  Careful!
Tenzin Gyatso shouts:
I need to jump! I love to jump!

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, THE POTALA NIGHT

text: The Nechung Oracle is the protective deity of Tibet. Tonight, he is in full trance.  It is an amazing sight. The monk who is his medium spins and twirls, he wags his heavy headdress about.  A round mirror glitters on his chest.  Sweat pours from his brow, over his wildly grimac face. The Oracle spits at the government officials in the room. Horns blow, cymbals crash, incense burns.  The Oracle nea the Dalai Lama and retreats from him.  Finally, he whispe in the boy's ear.
Heed the warning of your predecessor. Or the war will end here.
And then, the Oracle gently straightens Tenzin Gyatso's yellow robes, before the trance ends and the Oracle falls into the arms of his attendants.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS NIGHT

text: Wind whistles through the Potala's hallways and porticos. The Master of the Kitchen is clearing away the dinner dishes. The view of the floor reveals that a "toy" war is being waged. With a "Meccano" set, the young Dalai Lama has created wh looks like an airplane, and a tank.  These vehicles are manned by beautifully detailed lead soldiers - British Wo War One Field soldiers, French Legionaries and American Artillery men. Norbu Thundrup, is flying low with a tsampa~dough airplan He drops little tsampa-dough bombs from his hand.  He hit tank and knocks down a few lead soldiers.
Oh, nicely done, Norbu.  I will get you.
The Lord Chamberlain enters.
May I listen to the news with you, Holiness?
Please.
A large, old-fashioned, short-wave radio broadcasts that there is still a real war in progress.  The BBC report is the Pacific front.
How big is Tibet's army?
Roughly five thousand men.
Is that big?
No.  Not very big.
The Regent is adding men. And he bought rifles and ammunition from India. Mountain guns, too.
The broadcast reports news of the civil war in China.
Will we be in this war?
No.  This war is almost over.
Will we ever be in war?
The Lord Chamberlain is silent.  Norbu answers.
We have enemies.
The Chinese.
Yes.
But, surely, we are safe in Tibet. We don't believe in killing.
No, we don't.
Tenzin Gyatso gets to his feet and takes an atlas from hi table.   He lays the book open on the floor.
This is Britain.
Ahh.
Where is Poland?
The Lord chamberlain sits on the floor.  He points to Poland.
Where is Pearl Harbor?
The Master of the Kitchen comes to look at the atlas.
In the Pacific Ocean.  It is an island.  American territory.
Where is Alsace?
I do not know, Holiness.
Tenzin Gyatso turns to a well thumbed page:  Tibet.
This is Tibet. And this is China.
Ahh.
They all look at huge China.
Certainly, we are safe in Tibet.
No one answers. Finally, as Norbu Thundrup begins to gather up the tsampa dough:
We hope, Kundun.
Tenzin Gyatso turns to the Lord Chamberlain.
What was the warning of the Thirteenth Dalai Lama?
He warned about the future of Tibet.
Tell me.
When it is time.

His Holiness works on an old movie projector.  A white- haired, CHINESE MONK works with him.  The old Monk has ve little patience.  He bangs his hand on the table, and huf and puffs as the two try again to fiddle with this and th Tenzin Gyatso works diligently and calmly.
Patience is the first of the Six Perfections.
The old Monk mutters something in Chinese.  They thread a roll of dusty film into the reel and spin the wheel.  The film breaks.  The old monk bangs the table again.  The wo continues.
One day, we will get that automobile running.
The monks slaps his head in horrid anticipation.

A movie begins, shown on a piece of cloth tacked to a wal It is a newsreel - footage from World War One. The trenches. The boy goes up to the cloth screen and touches it gently playing with his own shadow as men dash from foxholes acr a muddy, body strewn field. The boy steps back and stares at the horror of real war; men sleeping in the muddy foxholes, make-shift hospitals tend the dying.  Youths - not much older than His Holines weep into their filthy, bloody hands. The Old Monk keeps his trembling hand on the noisy, hand- operated, projector. Tenzin Gyatso slowly sits, cross-legged, on the bare floo War does not look good on film.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, NORBULINKA NIGHT

text: The boy sits alone, in front of his altar, praying. Meditating.

head_text.subj: INT. ALTAR ROOM, THE NORBULINKA DAY

text: A black room, lit by butter lamps. Taktra Rinpoche and Tenzin Gyatso sit opposite one anothe cross-legged on the floor.  Taktra is the teacher, he sit bit higher. The room is a shrine to Mahakala, the Dalai Lama's person deity.  Mahakala is present, in the form of a huge, golde statue. The boy has his head bent low to catch the Rinpoche's wor There is much gesturing, much murmuring.  We might catch only a word or two. An oral teaching is being passed on, a lineage teaching. is sacred and secret.

head_text.subj: EXT. UPPER COURTYARD, THE POTALA DAY

text: CLOSE on a thangka of Penden Lhamo. We hear monks debating.  It is Ling Rinpoche answering, playing the student.
"To be born in a time when the Buddha has appeared. To be born in a time when the Buddha has taught. To be born when the teaching of Buddha is alive."
We find His Holiness, sitting, listening to the debate.
"To be born where the dharma is practiced. To be born in a time when people have compassion for other people."
The view widens now and we are under a softly billowing, appliqued canopy.  Maybe fifty monks and lamas are presen This is an informal group.
How is human life precious?

As a result of previous karma, you have obtained this human life. By means of this rebirth, through work and study, you can attain all everlasting happiness. In the words of Shantideva: "With the boat of this precious life, You can cross the waters of Samsara. How rare to find this boat!" "Oh, ignorant one, do not fall asleep now!"
Shots ring out. The men jump to their feet, and rush out from under the canopy.  The Dalai Lama is right in front. More shots as the men stare out across the countryside. We hear murmurs of:
Sera, Sera Monastery. Reting.  Under arrest.  The army is taking him right past Sera! Monastery!  Those crazy monks!  Have been threatening trouble. Reting tried to assassinate Taktra Rinpoche.
We hear these snippets as the Dalai Lama runs from the gr
It is almost black inside this old building.  The panting boy runs up and up and up several staircases.
Tenzin Gyatso runs down the hall and enters his red rooms

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS DAY

text: Norbu Thundrup is in the room and he moves ahead of the b - out to the terrace.
Tenzin Gyatso climbs up on a small, wooden platform, and mans his telescope.
It's the army, firing on Sera Monastery! Oh, no!  Oh, no!
The shooting continues.
Why is this?  What is happening? Tell me!

Reting Rinpoche has been arrested.  He tried to overthrow Regent Taktra. Today, he is brought back to Lhasa by government officials. The monks at Sera Monastery have been on his side.  Now, there is trouble between them and the army.
The Lord Chamberlain arrives on the terrace.
I am sorry for you to have to witness this, Kundun.
Look here!
The Lord Chamberlain peers through the telescope as the shooting continues.
Tragic.  Unnecessary.
The Lord Chamberlain steps away from the telescope and th boy takes his place. The shooting slowly stops.
Holiness? I have a letter.
The boy looks up.
The Thirteenth Dalai Lama's warning. He wrote to you, the year before he died.  The year before you were born.

The Lord Chamberlain walks to a far, sheltered end of the terrace. Tenzin Gyatso slowly turns the telescope to see the priso yard. View through the telescope;  the yard is full of prisoner listening to the shooting.  One man sees the telescope ai at the prison and prostrates.  Then another, and another. Tenzin Gyatso steps away from the telescope and turns to follow his Lord Chamberlain.

head_text.subj: EXT. OTHER SIDE OF TERRACE DAY

text: The Lord Chamberlain opens a yellowing letter and begins read.  Tenzin Gyatso sits down beside him.
"It may happen, that here in Tibet, religion and government will be attacked both from without and within. Unless we guard our own country..."
CLOSE on the Lord Chamberlain.  Today, he appears tired; the whites of his eyes appear enormous.  His voice is qui beautiful.
"...it will now happen that the Dalai and Panchen Lamas, the Father and the Son, and all the revered holders of the faith, will disappear and become nameless."
Tenzin Gyatso unwinds the rosary from his wrist and begin thumbing the brown beads.

"Monks and their monasteries will be destroyed. The rule of law will be weakened. The lands and properties will be seized.  They themselves will be forced to serve their enemies or wander the country like beggars." "All beings will be sunk in great hardship and overwhelming fear; the days and nights will drag on slowly in suffering."
He is finished.
What can I do?  I am only a boy.
You are the man who wrote this letter.  You are the man who has come back to lead us.   You will soon have great responsibilities.  You must know what to do.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, ADJACENT ROOM, DAY

text: The Regent and the Lord Chamberlain are present. Also present is the KASHAG - a council of four men:  one monk, three laymen.  They are the Dalai Lama's advisory cabinet.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOM DAY

text: The boy rises from his desk.  Norbu says:
You remember who you are. You called for them.
Tenzin Gyatso enters the adjacent room.
The boy climbs onto a cushion and sits - a head above his officials.  He is tentative, unsure of form and procedure There is an awkward, formal silence.  Then:
Taktra Rinpoche, I understand there was an attempt on your life.
It is possible, Holiness.
You are unharmed?
Completely.
Good.  Where is Reting Rinpoche now?
He has been imprisoned, here in the Potala, Holiness.
The Sera monks have surrendered?
It is calm.
The boy motions to the table.
Please, have tea.
The tea is poured.
I need to know what you know.  I am no longer a child.
Ask whatever you will.
What is the danger from the Chinese, now?

Very complicated, Holiness. Let me tell you current news. The Chinese have launched a deceptive campaign aimed at convincing the world that Tibet belongs to China. We sent a mission to the Chinese National Conference.  Our attendance was a grave mistake.  The Tibetans were introduced as delegates from the "Chinese region of Tibet". We protested this reference and demanded a letter rebutting it.
Did you receive the letter?
We did not.
The war is over. This is a time in when nations are redefining themselves.
So, Tibet, too, needs to define itself.
Yes.  As a free country. But our attempts have proven futile.  We continue to be badly outmaneuvered by the Chinese.
Can India help us?
India is a newly independent nation.  They are struggling. India is in no position to help us.
Britain?
Britain chooses not to.
And, America?
America, we shall see.
Ask the Chinese mission to leave our country.  Immediately.
A shocking suggestion.
Quite simple.  Yes.  Good.
I shall send a letter to America, to the President, informing him of our problem.
The men agree to this.
I want Reting Rinpoche well cared for.  He is my teacher.  He found me.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOM NIGHT

text: The Dalai Lama sits at his desk, writing a letter. The radio is on.  It is the BBC - with news of a Communis advantage in Kuomintang China. Norbu Thundrup enters.  The boy looks up.
Listen to this, Norbu. (he reads):

To Mr Truman The President of the United States of America I am glad that you are enjoying the best of health and doing good service to uplift the happiness and prosperity of the whole world.  Here, I am well and doing my best for the religion of Lord Buddha and welfare of all beings. This is all, so far.
Reting Rinpoche has died in prison.
Tenzin Gyatso lays down his pen.

Tenzin Gyatso is alone.  He has a little smelting arrangement built out on the terrace.  He lays a lead soldier on the hot bottom of a heavy, metal bowl. CLOSE on the soldier.  It begins to melt. The boy has a pile of the soldiers.  He drops a second on in the bowl. We bear the sounds of Lhasa - laughter, street songs - an we see the stars, hanging, it seems, just above the young boy's head.
The young Tenzin Gyatso bursts through the gate in the Yellow Wall and runs across the beautiful garden to his parents's home.

A family gathering meets the boy's eye when he enters. There is his Mother, his oldest sister, Tsering Dolma, Lobsang Samten, a younger sister, Pema, baby brother Tend Chuta, and his oldest brother, Takster. We don't recognize these faces, of course, but the gather is obviously familial. Only the boy's Father is missing. Tenzin Gyatso goes to his Mother and lays his head in her lap. On an altar behind her, is a silver frame.  In the frame a picture of her husband.

The body of the Dalai Lama's Father lays on a flat boulde Incense smoke curls into the air.  Prayer wheels are turn hand drums are played - the burial men stand off to one side, their hatchets and knives in view. Tenzin Gyatso is present.  He is the boy we know, but bes him stands the four year-old boy, Lhamo, from the beginni of the movie, and on the other side of him stands the boy who will play the Dalai Lama in the next section of the f -  a boy about fifteen or sixteen. Tenzin Gyatso wraps his brown rosary around his left wris The beads catch the brilliant afternoon light.  The sixte year-old Dalai Lama wears the same colored rosary around left wrist. The cutters move in to the corpse, and as we hear them be the work of dismembering the body, the view pans up to reveal the vultures circling overhead. The last person leaving the hilltop with is the Dalai Lam as an older man - not a character from this movie - but a man of about fifty years, wearing glasses, wearing the sa robes, the same rosary.  Little Lhamo walks beside him.

We hear a loud explosion, and then another and another an another.  The sound begins to fade, but the blue-black, peaceful, star-filled sky is shattered by bright bursts o red and yellow and pink light. It is a frightening sight.
The still waters of the fish pond begin to move.  The fis swim in nervous circles;  the water laps over its stone banks.

The whole building shakes.  Earthquake. One monk runs down the stairs, another monk runs up, both staring at a second floor window - a black-rimmed, glass window. A red cloth is pulled back and the window is opened. The fifteen year-old Tenzin Gyatso looks out. There is a terrible rumbling:  the rumbling that accompan an earthquake.  Finally, slowly, the sound, and the movem subsides. CLOSE on Tenzin Gyatso.  He lets the curtain fall.

head_text.subj: INT. GREAT HALL, THE POTALA DAY

text: The General Assembly is in session. Once again, the Yigstang and the Tsitang - four monks and four laymen - sit facing one another.  But the room is crowded today - this is a full session.  The Lord chamberlain sits in.  Regent Taktra is there. The senior Layman is on his knees.
The Communist have control of China.
In the back of the room we notice an open door.
The Dalai Lama is listening.  He stands taller than the first time we caught him eavesdropping.  He still is not part of this assembly, but he doesn't seem to care if he spotted.
The Layman continues.
Now, as his great army, stands idle on our borders, Chairman Mao has presented Tibet with three demands: One, Tibet must accept that it is part of China.
A murmuring in the room.
Shock on the face of His Holiness.
Two, Tibet's defenses must be handled by China. Three, all political and trade matters concerning foreign countries must be conducted through China.
A voice shouts out:
Give the Dalai Lama his majority!
The senior Monk is on his knees.
We can concede that Tibet is a part of China if we can guarantee that the Dalai Lama's name and authority will remain...
And do you believe that the Tibetan government will be allowed to continue to function as it is? Do you believe that our religion will be protected?
Give the Dalai Lama his majority!
We have dealt with this Chinese obsession for hundreds of years. We can deal with it now.
These are not the Chinese we know. These are Communists.
Make him Dalai Lama now!
We see the Lord Chamberlain look toward the open door.

Tenzin Gyatso looks at his advisor, and then, he closes t door as the demand for his enthronement continues. He walks down the hall, past the door leading to the treasure room, alone now - an adult.  He is wearing those European, lace-up shoes found in the treasure room so lon ago.  They are still too big for him.

head_text.subj: EXT. TRIBUTARY OF THE KYICHU RIVER, NORBULINKA DAY

text: Tenzin Gyatso and Taktra Rinpoche walk side by side along the waterway.
If we agree that we are part of China, nothing else will matter. Not trade, not defense. We will be lost.
What would you do, Holiness?
The boy looks out over the water. Shepherds are leading their flock of sheep back toward to on the far side of the tributary. The two men stand side by side, one so young, one seeming old.
What should I do about my doubt, Teacher?
It is a difficult situation.
I mean, my doubt.  Why me? Am I Him?
Doubt is an affliction.  Reliquish it.  Accept.
Pause.
I believe we must make no concesions to the Chinese.  But, I am one voice. The Dalai Lama has always trusted in the forces of Buddha.  Let us consult the protective deities.

Taktra Rinpoche bows and leaves him. Tenzin Gyatso stands alone by the river.  The boy watches the herders, and before the young shepherds disappear fro sight, the Dalai Lama turns and waves a hand behind him. Two Bodyguards approach.  We can not hear, but as the Dal Lama walks away from us, down the river, one Bodyguard ru up river, shouting: BODYGUARD (shouting) We will buy them!  We will buy them!

In this black room, under the protective view of the stat of Mahakala, a divine lottery is performed. Tenzin Gyatso, the Regent Taktra Rinpoche, The Lord chamberlain, the Kashag, the Yigstang and the Tsitang are all present. Tsampa-dough balls are made, three of them, each containi a strip of parchment, bearing writing.  The dough is shap and weighed to see that each ball is equal. Then, the three balls are placed in a silver bowl and the bowl is spun.  The balls whirl, race, and finally one lea from the bowl. This ball is taken to the Dalai Lama and he makes a mark it.  The ball is returned to the bowl, the procedure is repeated, and a ball leaps again, almost immediately.  Th ball is presented and the Dalai Lama places his mark - ne to the mark he just made.  It is the same ball. Tenzin Gyatso makes the twelfth mark on the same ball, an the spinning begins again and then the thirteenth mark, a then the ball is broken open and the strip of parchment handed to the Regent.
We should not accept any conditions from the Chinese.

In a paved area, adjacent to the Yellow Wall which marks Dalai Lama's private grounds, the Opera Festival has begu This festival involves performances by Tibetan singers, dancers and actors.  It looks to be a joyous occasion; officials and their wives are dressed in their finest and sit before beautifully laid picnics.  Children run here a there, amidst the monks and nomads, the swashbuckling Khambas from eastern Tibet (large people, with heavy brai wrapped in red cloth on top of their heads).  There are westerners, Nepalese and Sikimese. Dancers - dressed in wild, colorful outfits - spin and le in time to the eerie, Tibetan music. Atop a low building on the Yellow Wall, stands an elabora enclosure - draped in yellow silk. The Dalai Lama sits inside it.
Tenzin Gyatso is alone in this little room;  his arms res on a window ledge as he stares down at the festival takin place below him.

A bit more of the dancers and the people enjoying themsel - all from the isolated point of view of the Dalai Lama. We recognize a few characters:  Keustang Rinpoche.  His Holiness's Mother with her younger children, the favorite sweeper, Norbu Thundrup - dressed in a fine hat. But a distant figure becomes apparent - he is a MESSENGER he is running, through the crowds, toward the Yellow Wall We stay on this desperate little figure as he draws close
The boy is watching the Messenger.
Back to that messenger as he works his way, ever closer t the building which holds the Dalai Lama aloft, and then w lose sight of him.
Tenzin Gyatso leans back in his seat.  The yellow silk curtain that his elbows have held open now fall closed an we hear the heavy footsteps of the runner. A knock.
Enter.

The Regent is next door. The boy climbs up on a chest and peeks through a tiny win in the wall which separates this enclosure from the Regent's. Taktra Rinpoche reads a telegram.  His aging face becomes quite grave. The Regent leaves his side of the enclosure.
Summon the Lord Chamberlain and the Kashag.
And then, there is a knock on the Dalai Lama's door.
Enter.
It is the Regent.
Holiness.
Yes.
The Chinese have invaded.
Back to a new group of performers - satirists, dressed as high lamas and monks - even as the Nechung Oracle - lampooning the rulers.  The crowd roars with laughter.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, NORBULINKA DUSK

text: The Lord Chamberlain stands with the teenage Dalai Lama. The room is a violent red in the sunset. Tenzin Gyatso has cleared off his table, he is creating a three-dimensional battlefield as his Lord Chamberlain explains the situation.  Tenzin Gyatso uses papers, books little statues to bring a physical life to the words we hear.
They crossed the river, Holiness. They have invaded in six locations, Chando Province, Kham, eastern Tibet.
What is the size of our army, now?
Eight thousand, five hundred, soldiers and officers. We have recently requested mortars, anti-aircraft guns and ammunition from India.  We have several hundred in the area.
Little statues are placed facing what stands-in for the river. The Lord Chamberlain helps the boy to create this panoram
Has anyone died?
The radio contact said one officer had died.  Then he said, "The Chinese soldiers - they are coming." And then, the radio went dead.
Tenzin Gyatso lifts one statue, a small, golden Buddha, f the display.  He cradles the Buddha in his hands.
One man.  A man has died. One man is too many.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, NORBULINKA DAY

text: In beautiful sunlight, the painted cabinets of this room glisten.  Rainbows of color play on the glass windows.  T Dalai Lama sits at a low table, a pack of colored pencils or pastels, spread out around him.  He is teaching his little brother to draw. Together, little hand in bigger hand, they draw. The Dalai Lama's Mother sits in a side chair, watching he sons. The little boy screams with laughter as the brothers draw yak.

A movie is being shown - outside - on a makeshift screen. It is "Henry the Fourth". This is a treat for the sweepers, and gardeners and servants.  children sit on the grass, mesmerized by this incredible vision. Tenzin Gyatso sits beside Heinrich Harrer. The boy rubs his eyes wearily.  He appears distracted. This line is spoken by an actor:
"Heavy lies the head, that wears the crown."
CLOSE on Tenzin Gyatso.

The Dalai Lama sits behind the wheel of a 1927 Austin. He is a lousy driver - a boy who never commanded a wheeled vehicle in all of his young life. The Attendants sit in the back seat, holding on for dear life. We hear Tenzin Gyatso's wonderful, deep laugh.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOM, THE POTALA NIGHT

text: Tenzin Gyatso is listening to Peking Radio.  Norbu Thundr is with him. The boy tinkers with a clock as he listens - he is swiftl becoming a master tinkerer.

"This week, the People's Liberation Army crossed the Drichu River east of Chamdo and began the peaceful liberation of Tibet. Tibet is in the hands of imperialist enemies of the people.  The Dalai Lama, a foolish reminder of an illiterate past, is the figure head of this autonomous region of China.  Accept our help, Tibet!  The people shall be free!"
What do the people say, Norbu?
Norbu is not shy in his report.

Tibetan officials have retreated from Chamdo.  They are scared and running.  The Chinese strategy has destroyed the heart of our defense forces.  Chamdo falls, several other villages are lost.  You know what happens.  The road to Lhasa will be wide open.
Tenzin Gyatso listens carefully to the man.
The people want you made Dalai Lama.
Then, I am lucky. I am still too young.
These are dangerous times. They want the Dalai Lama to lead them.
But, I have no experience.
Oh, but you do, Kundun. Who else would be here?

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, THE POTALA NIGHT

text: The Nechung Oracle spins in his trance.  Horns blow, cymb clash, the Oracle spurts sounds as lamas chant. Finally, the Oracle approaches the boy, stands beside him like a lieutenant, a comrade, and says:
"His time has come."
The Dalai Lama is reading - Tibet's appeal to the United Nations.

"To the members of the United Nations: The attention of the world is riveted on Korea where aggression is being resisted by an international force.  Similar happenings in remote Tibet are passing without notice. The problem is not of Tibet's own making but is largely the outcome of unthwarted Chinese ambition to bring weaker nations on her periphery within her active domination." This is very good.  Quite strong.
The Lord Chamberlain and the four members of the Kashag agree. The boy continues:
"Tibetans have for long lived a cloistered life in their mountain fastness, remote and aloof..."

In the background, we see monks on top of a wall, long ho in front of them.  The blowing begins. In a courtyard below, a debating session is in progress. hear the shouts and the claps and watch the beautiful bod movements of the questioners.  Laughter fills the air. Below that, the small capital of Tibet - the mysterious city, the forbidden city of Lhasa - carries on, for now.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, THE POTALA NIGHT

text: A monk - an abbot, in fact - sits beside Tenzin Gyatso. It is Takster Rinpoche, the Dalai Lama's oldest brother.
I was never alone.  Two Chinese were with me every minute of the day.
Tenzin Gyatso plays with a box of those special sweets wh comes from his mother.
Their talk is always of liberation and helpfulness.  They put their words like honey on a knife, but if you lick the honey, you will bleed.
Takster Rinpoche begins to say something, but holds back.
Tell me.

They think they have convinced me. They think I am on their side. They have allowed me to leave Kumbum and come to Lhasa believing that I will try to turn you to their ways. If I do not succeed, I am to eliminate you.
You, kill me?
Eliminate you.
The tension is great, the idea profound.
I can be Governor of Lhasa, they say.
The brothers try to resist, but cannot.  They laugh like crazy.
Don't eat all those sweets. You'll get sick.
Do you remember the day I came to your monastery, when I was a baby? And you comforted me?
I do.
I remember, too, actually. I was frightened then. I am frightened now.
The Chinese have one goal.  The complete dissolution of our nation. The destruction of our culture. There is no room for Buddha in their world. Our only hope is to fight.
We cannot.
This is not a fight to put bread just in one's own mouth. This is a fight for Tibet.
Buddha teaches that we must learn from our enemy.  We have compassion for all people.
These are not human beings. They are worse than ghosts.
Silence.
You are in great danger. The Dalai Lama cannot fall into Chinese hands. You must flee.
How could I ever leave?
It may not be your decision to make.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, THE POTALA DAY

text: In the adjacent room, the four members of the Kashag and Lord Chamberlain are waiting. The Dalai Lama enters the room. The boy goes to a small table where a document is unrolle before him. Tenzin Gyatso lifts the gold seal of power and affixes it the document.
I accept it.
He makes his mark on a small piece of parchment that is attached to the document. He has accepted the request to be enthroned.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS HOUR BEFORE DAWN

text: The Master of the Robe is helping Tenzin Gyatso to dress. He ties a piece of green cloth around his waist and helps him on with his maroon robes. Norbu is there, watching.
Tenzin Gyatso walks down this dark hall.  The three attendants are with him.

It is very dark green.  Butter lamps highlight certain fa - members of the Kashag, noblemen, the tutors, an Englishman, Nepalese, Bhutanese, Tibetan Muslims - but th darkness conceals the great number of people present. We hear the unmistakable Tibetan horns and cymbals. We he the chanting of monks. The boy is handed a Golden Wheel, symbolizing the assumpt of temporal power. At one moment, the Lamas all put on their yellow hats - a color that peeks at us out of this dark room.  And we hea voice:
We shall send delegations to America, India, Nepal and Great Britain, in hope that these countries will intervene on our behalf.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, THE POTALA DAY

text: The Dalai Lama addresses the Yistang, the Tsitang. Two new faces are present.
We have telegraphed our appeal to the United Nations and await its reply. I am sending a delegation to China to negotiate the Chinese withdrawal.
He looks around these rooms.
It seems that I must depart Lhasa. The majority wills it. Lukhangwa and Lobsang Tashi?
The two men rise to their knees - LUKHANGWA, an incredibl looking layman, with a long white beard, and LOBSANG TASH a monk.
I am making you my Prime Ministers. You will stay here. You must always keep me informed, no matter how bad the news. I want plain information.
The men bow to His Holiness.
Today, I declare a general amnesty. I have always wanted to free the prisoners.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, THE POTALA DUSK

text: Tenzin Gyatso is packing.  We hear whispers in the adjace room as the Masters of the Robe and the Ritual organize belongings into piles:  rolled thangkas, precious manuscripts, maroon robes, a few english books, the radio The boy finds a few golden coins in a drawer and slips th into his robes. Tenzin Gyatso adds a package of tools, an atlas, the phot of the Thirteenth Dalai Lama, the European shoes.  Then, goes to the terrace.

The boy does not need a footstool anymore. He glides the telescope across the countryside, catching sight of the young herders leading their sheep back into town.  He picks up a corner of the market place and the h bub of the end of the day.  Wall posters show Tibetan soldiers fleeing the Red Army. And then, he aims his view-finder at the prison yard. It is empty.  The prisoners are gone.
It's time to take this down.
Tenzin Gyatso lets go of the eyepiece and turns to see Norbu.
You will not come?
No, Holiness.
Am I running away?
The people will cry when they learn you are gone. But they would all want you safe.
Together, the friends break-down the telescope.
Let me take this.
Norbu folds up the tripod.
You must study very hard, do not neglect the holy things during this time.
I will miss you.
We have had fun, you and I. Fun for a little boy in an old palace.
We have.
You have grown up very good.
And you have grown older and your chin has grown balder.
Norbu laughs.  The telescope is wrapped.
Tonight, Kundun, you see the world. You place your feet on the shepherd boy's path.
Norbu Thundrup ties a tight knot in a cord.
"The Gods will be avenged."
CLOSE on the gold seal of state as it is packed in a silk lined box.

Tenzin Gyatso - dressed in the warm, woolen chuba of a layman - keeps his back against the wall.  Norbu is besid him, carrying a flashlight. A Bodyguard comes for them, and then, the Dalai Lama is outside the Potala walls.

The small group walks down a rocky path.  A grey horse is waiting. Tenzin Gyatso is helped onto the horse.  Norbu sees that is comfortable, and then, the flashlight goes out.  Norbu fiddles with it.  Tenzin Gyatso takes the torch and tries get it working again.  The Guard mounts his horse.  It is time to go.  The horses snort, their breath consolidating the cold night air. Tenzin Gyatso cannot speak.  He tries, but he cannot.  No takes the flashlight.
I will send it to you. It will work.
The horse is turned and the Dalai Lama is led away to joi the soldiers at the foot of the path. Tenzin Gyatso turns once, to see his friend.  The night i dark.  Norbu has become invisible.

A cold and moonless night, lit only by the millions of st that shine over Tibet.  The caravan - made up of noblemen monks, family mambers and over two hundred soldiers (arme with rifles, machine guns and field artillery) - journeys out of Lhasa. CLOSE on the Dalai Lama:  riding the shepherd's path.
Tenzin Gyatso rides his grey horse through a gate in the yellow wall.
The boy climbs the stairs to his summer residence.
The shrine of Mahakala.  Butter lamps cast their eerie gl on the black walls as the boy presents a white, silk scar a kata - a traditional token of leaving and return.

Tenzin Gyatso is about to leave the residence when he sto and looks at the small cabinet in the corner.  He goes to it. The door is still locked. CLOSE on the boy.  Suddenly, he knows. He reaches a hand behind the cabinet.  The hand comes bac to him with a key. Tenzin Gyatso opens the cabinet doors.  Several drawers a revealed. The boy opens one.  Empty.  Another.  Empty. A Bodyguard says, from the stairs:
We must go, Holiness.
A moment.

Another drawer.  Empty.  And then, success. In a small drawer, there is something, wrapped in red velvet. The boy opens it, with shaking hands.  Teeth.  False teet Tenzin Gyatso releases a sharp laugh, he has been holding his breath.   He wraps up the teeth and puts them back, b behind the teeth is something more. A rolled, white silk scarf, a kata. Tenzin Gyatso takes the scarf.  He unrolls it.  Something falls on the floor. A tiny, lead soldier. Tenzin Gyatso lifts the soldier.  It is a Ghurka.  An Ind soldier.
Please, come, Holiness.
Yes.  I am ready.
The boy places the scarf around his own shoulders.
Safe journey.  Safe return. I am him.
CLOSE on the golden statue of Mahakala, wearing his white scarf. We hear the roar of the Kyichu river.

Coracles - skin boats - are loaded with bundles and peopl and pushed off the banks and into the water. Horses, donkeys and yaks must swim across. Tenzin Gyatso is helped into a boat.  The rowers, wrapped heavy wool and sheepskin, their arms bare, push off. The boy is sprayed with water.  He is bumped about.  He i freezing cold.  He floats away from Lhasa.

The caravan journeys through a narrow mountain pass. The flags of Tibet and of the Dalai Lama are carried by mounted soldiers. Suddenly, monks come running from the surrounding mountai trails, shrieking, wailing. They run to lamas, grabbing at their robes, clutching, crying out:
Do not let him go! We beg of you, do not take him from us!

One monk clutches for an instant at the layman's wrapping Tenzin Gyatso - but he does not recognize him as the Dala Lama The boy tenderly embraces this distraught figure, but the monk drops away from him and clings to the shy, sweet presence of Ling Rinpoche. The Dalai Lama is quickly and quietly surrounded by soldi - discreetly, so as not to give away his identity. Ling Rinpoche speaks to a group.
He goes for a short time, until the danger can be determined.  He will not leave Tibet.  He will return.

The pain on these monks's faces, in their voices, is trag Tenzin Gyatso is overwhelmed. He sees before him a line of prostrate monks - but they a not bowing to him, they are laying down in the pass, tryi to block the way of the caravan. Ling Rinpoche goes to these men and gently helps them to their feet.
He will return. The Precious One will not abandon you.
The Dalai Lama lies awake in his camp bed.  He cannot sle He rises and walks to the tent flap.  He opens it.

A Bodyguard is posted.  He turns to the Dalai Lama. We recognize him.  He is the Bodyguard from that first caravan trip so long ago:  a huge monk with a big stick - the guard who stood outside the old monks's tent.  The ma with the deformed face. The boy is not frightened this time.
All quiet?
Yes, Holiness.
Where are you from?
Kham, Holiness.
Your people are very brave. They are fighting the Chinese. No one can stop them. Not even me.
Khambas are wild men.
There is silence as the two men look out at the cold nigh
I worry about them.
Do not worry, Holiness. They fight for you. They are under your protection.
The boy steps back inside.
We hear the approach of a horse, and then the Bodyguard enters the tent.
Holiness, this has come for you.

The Bodyguard hands the boy a parcel.  Tenzin Gyatso unwr it.  His flashlight.  It works. A pause, and then Tenzin Gyatso sits in front of the than of Penden Lhamo. He reads from the scripture pages laid out on the low tab He reads by flashlight.
The Dalai Lama walks along a beaten, caravan path.  He is still in disguise, and obviously, enjoying it. An OLD MUSLIM MAN is beside him - an incredible looking creature.
Eighteen children.
Eighteen, wonderful.
And not a monk among them.
The Dalai Lama laughs.

No, no son of mine will sit and read books and eat up the poor people's butter while my people have to butcher the cows and sheep because these holy men can't kill an animal.  They can eat it, can't they?
The boy laughs again.
Still walking, with two companions.  A Tibetan peasant WOMAN, and his own mother.
Did you love your husband, before you married?
I did not know him before I married him.  I loved his brother, but then, I married his brother, too.  He is dead now.
Hmm.
The land has stayed in the family. We work together.  The nobleman is not too bad.
Does he treat you fairly?
A laugh from her.
Not too bad.  Rich is rich, poor is poor.  We are different. Are you married?
Tenzin Gyatso laughs. The Attendants walk behind the boy, eavesdropping.  Tenzi Gyatso's Mother plays along.
No.
Too young?
Much too young.
Look for a strong woman, not too occupied with her beauty. Look for a woinan who keeps her hands busy.  Look for a kind heart.
Like my mother.
I see that.
The Dalai Lama walks beside two boys: his older brother, Lobsang, and a YOUNG NOBLE BOY.

This little brother was terribly sweet.  When he died, my mother was so sad.  A lama said to her, before the little brother was laid out for burial, take a bit of butter and rub a spot on his skin.  He will come back to you, you will see. So, my mother did this, and a few years later, a new boy was born.
Does he have the spot?
He does, a little spot where the butter had been.
Is that a true story, or pretend?
What do you think?
True.
You decide.
They walk.
What does the butter spot feel like?
Soft.  Nice. I have a good friend back in Lhasa.  He has a very poor beard, with a little spot on his chin where no hair grows.  It feels like that.
It is raining as we see the Dalai Lama on horseback, climbing the dirt path leading to this beautiful, small monastery.  The caravan has arrived at its destination. We hear the chanting of monks.

location: THE DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, DUNGKAAR MONASTERY

text: A home has been made:   books on the shelf, screwdrivers in a row, European shoes under the bed.  An old Bush radi receiver, running off a six-volt battery, sits on the flo The telescope stands on the terrace. Two members of the Kashag can be seen in the adjacent roo The rooms are stark white.
Of the Tibetan delegations sent abroad, all have been turned away.
All?
Tenzin Gyatso, dressed informally, looking peaceful, sits with his advisors on the floor.  The Lord Chamberlain is with them.
Britain, Nepal, America, India. All of those governments have refused to meet with our representatives.
Silence.
And the United Nations?  Surely?
The United Nations voted not to hear our appeal.
One country did sponsor the resolution.  A land called "El Salvador".
Where is that?
In the Americas.
Silence.
So, we must face China and all her might alone.

Yes. Most of the Chamdo region is now in Chinese hands.  There is a report from Chamdo which makes quite clear that, unless some settlement can soon be reached, Communist troops will soon be marching on Lhasa.
With much bloodshed.
I am afraid.
I want at all costs to avoid this. Do we have news from the delegation in China?
Not yet, but the Governor of Chamdo, Ngabo Jigme, suggests we must negotiate and offers to go to Peking.
He is a capable man.
Your prime minsters would argue that such negotiations should take place in Lhasa.
And then they would concede that the times are desperate and we must go to Peking.  Agreed.  Send Ngabo. Is that all?
Yes.
Time to study.
The boy gets up.  The prostrations begin.
Wait.
Tenzin Gyatso waves a hand. The men get up, awkwardly.
We are in the last outposts of Tibet. Let's do away with some of this formality.
