The Dalai Lama leaves the room. One man still goes down to his knees.
He is a modern man. Just like he was the last time.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS DUSK

text: Ling Rinpoche and Tenzin Gyatso sit together.
"I will liberate those not liberated." I will release those not released. I will relieve those not relieved. May I deliver them to the state of enlightenment."
The lead soldier of the Indian Ghurka sits on the low tab beside Buddha and the tantric instruments.
Tenzin Gyatso walks alone in the mountains.  We see his Bodyguards in the distance.  He comes to a chorten (a stu - a small, pagoda-like chapel).  He steps inside.

This is where the Tibetan peasants come to make their offerings to Buddha.  It is a small space, whitewashed, quiet.  A painting of Buddha adorns one wall and flowers, butter lamps, nuts and dried fruit sit before it. The boy looks closer. There is a photograph pinned to the wall. It is a picture of him, as a young boy.  The Incarnate. Precious One.
The Dalai Lama ties his piece of colored cloth, his mantr to this public prayer flag.  The beautiful valley lies at his feet, the bodyguards keep a polite distance.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS NIGHT

text: The boy is tinkering, as he listens to the radio. It is Peking Radio he is picking up. We hear a crackly voice begin a very important announceme

"Today in Peking, a Seventeen Point Agreement for the peaceful Liberation of Tibet has been signed by Representatives of the Government of the People's Republic of China and the Local Government of Tibet."
Tenzin Gyatso drops his work.  He turns to face the offending radio.

"Over the last hundred years or more aggressive, imperialist forces have penetrated into Tibet and carried out all manner of deceptions and provocations.  Under such conditions the Tibetan nationality was plunged into the depths of enslavement and suffering."
The boy moves closer to the radio, he appears physically ill.

"Today, this enslavement ends. Point One:  The Tibetan people shall unite and drive out imperialist aggressive forces from Tibet. The Tibetan people shall return to the big family of the Motherland - the People's Republic of China." Point Two: The Local Government of Tibet will actively assist the People's Liberation Army to enter Tibet and consolidate the national defense."
Tenzin Gyatso is stunned.  Frozen.
It means we have lost our status as an independent nation.
Tenzin Gyatso, the two members of the Kashag and the Lord Chamberlain stand around a clicking telegraph machine.  A long message curls along the floor.
Ngabo did not have the state seal.  He could not sign.
Yes, but they say he did.
A Kashag Member is reading along as the message comes in.
Holiness?
Yes.
General Chiang Chin-wu, the Chinese representative, is en route to Dromo. He is coming to meet you.
Then, we shall meet.

View through the telescope:  the Chinese are coming. A group of officials are headed in the direction of the monastery.  Within the group of Tibetan noblemen - dresse in their traditional red and gold silk robes - are three men, wearing drab, grey suits. The Chinese men closer and we see that one of them is smoking a cigarette. CLOSE on Tenzin Gyatso's face.

The Chinese Delegation, led by GENERAL CHIANG CHIN-WU, stands waiting in a dimly-lit, yellow room. A table holds tea and refreshments. The Dalai Lama and his cabinet members are in the room. Chairs are provided.
Dalai Lama.
General Chiang.
We bring greetings from Chairman Mao.
Thank you.  Please sit.
The General does.  So does the Dalai Lama. The other two Chinese remain standing. Tenzin Gyatso is quiet, reserved.  Awkward.
Have you heard the terms of the Seventeen Point Agreement?
I have.
I have a copy for you.
A document is produced.  We notice that the General is wearing a gold rolex watch.  The Dalai Lama notices, too. A member of the Kashag takes the document.
We come in genuine friendship.
CLOSE on the Dalai Lama. He makes no response.
I am certain you wish to return to Lhasa.
Tenzin Gyatso remains silent.
Do you have plans to return soon, Dalai Lama?
Soon.
Good.  Our first request is that you allow us to build a road.  You have no roads in Tibet.  We can discuss the plans in Lhasa.  When you return.
No response.
Thank you.  We leave now.
The General rises as the boy remains seated.  With a mome of awkward silence, the Chinese depart.
Let me see the agreement.
It is handed to him.  He opens to the last page and looks the impression made by the state seal.
Counterfeit.
He closes the document and hands it back to the official.
The boy watches the delegation leave the hilltop station. Taktra Rinpoche and the Lord Chamberlain are with him.
I thought he would be some kind of monster, even with horns growing out of his head.  But, he is only a man, just an ordinary human being, like myself.  Life is always a lesson.

head_text.subj: EXT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS DAY

text: Again, an informal meeting is in session.
Your Prime Ministers, support the proposal that you return to Lhasa. On the opposite hand, some officials urge you not to return.  They believe you should leave now, for India.
If I were to go into exile, could we expect any serious assistance, from India, suppose?
It is unlikely.  America, perhaps. There is great anti-communist feeling in America.
At this point, the most likely result of a foreign pact is war.
The Chinese would see such a pact as an open declaration of war.
Tibet, at war?  No. China is close, America is far away.  After countless people die, China would still, always, be close.  We will work with what we have.
And as for your own safety, Holiness?
A pause.
I am scared.
Shall we consult the protective deities, Holiness?
My first and foremost duty is to protect my people.  I feel sure of this. And, things change.  Maybe not right away, maybe not soon.  But I believe this - things will change.
The boy snaps his fingers.
Impermanence. Our own short lifetimes are not the only valid consideration. I shall return.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS NIGHT

text: Tenzin Gyatso is asleep.  We have not seen him this still this peaceful, in a long time.  He sleeps in the "Buddha~ pose" - on his right side9 his head resting in his right hand.  The wall behind him is white. We begin to hear the unique Tibetan music.

Tenzin Gyatso rides a grey mule across the empty, mysteri landscape of Tibet. The boy is back in his own home in Amdo province. But, he is not the baby he was when he left there, he is sixteen.  His family is together, but they are all the si and ages they were at the beginning of the story.  Tenzin Gyatso is very happy, sitting on the raised platform in t kitchen, playing a game with pebbles. Taktra Rinpoche - the aged Taktra - enters and sits down beside him.
I hope you will not feel badly about all the things of childhood you missed.
The boy does not speak, just looks, kindly, at the man.
You lost so much.  I am sorry.
The boy shakes his head "no".
Goodbye, Kundun.
Suddenly, another man speaks;
Goodbye, Kundun.
Tenzin Gyatso turns his head to see his best friend.
(he only mouths it) No!
And now, the Dalai Lama's Father is seen in a corner of t kitchen.
Goodbye, Kundun. TENZIN GYATSO (silent) No!
The boy turns to the sweeper once more, holds out his han and mouths:
No, Norbu!
Reverse on Norbu, fading away.
Tenzin Gyatso eyes burst open.  He is awake.  He is older Twenty.  But, there is something ageless about him, now.

location: DALAI LAMA'S ROOM, THE POTALA PRE-DAWN

text: The boy begins this day. He is in his old room at the Potala, in Lhasa.  The green mural of the Fifth Dalai Lama is behind him.  He has rise from the red-curtained bed. The Masters of the Kitchen and the Robe arrive and begin their preparations for the day. A NEW SWEEPER works in the adjacent room. The sun rises.
Like a painting, the beautiful monastery fills the screen with its white walls and red roof. Shouting is heard.
I hate meeting here, this tribute to the past!  I demand a less formal meeting place.
CLOSE on the red, bulging face of General Chiang.

head_text.subj: INT. GREAT HALL, THE POTALA DAY

text: Behind the General hang fantastic thangkas of the Fifth Dalai Lama.
I am not a foreigner! I refuse to be treated like one.
The Dalai Lama is shaken by this violent behavior. He adjusts his new eye glasses.
You see here thangkas of the Fifth Dalai Lama, the founder of our government.  It is tradition at formal meetings for these thangkas to be hung.
Superstitions.  Tibet is part of a modern nation.
The General sits.
I want the songs stopped.
Songs?  What songs?
A slight smile.
Street songs about the General. Reference to his gold watch. He is right, they are quite insulting.
I have no authority to ban singing in my country.
You must also do something about the public meetings.  I see this, memorandum circulating, with Tibetan grievances.
You have cracked a man's skull and that crack has not healed. It is too soon to expect him to be your friend.
We are simply respecting the terms of the Seventeen Point Agreement.
Are you, General?
We want 2,000 more tons of barley distributed.
Impossible!  You will bring famine down on the people of Tibet with these insatiable demands! More food, the best land for your soldiers to camp.
The People's Liberation Army pays for all food and lodging.
So far, they do. But, the quantity, it does not exist.  You will have to re- evaluate your needs.
The men glare at one another.
How much tea do you drink, Prime Minister?
It depends on the quality. And, that it be Indian.
The General leaps to his feet and is about to strike the Prime Minister. The Dalai Lama runs between then.  He holds the General back.
Why is it necessary for the Chinese to keep so many soldiers in Lhasa?
To protect.  To serve you. Chairman Mao wants you to feel that China belongs to you now.
Chairman Mao can keep China. Just give us back Tibet.
The General backs away and brings himself under control.
Plans for absorbing the Tibetan army into the People's Army will soon be finalized.
I will not approve it.
Then, we will begin with replacing the Tibetan flag with the flag of the Motherland.
And we will begin with tearing it down.
Tenzin Gyatso stands between these furious men.  He raise hand, silently requesting peace.

We hear the sound of martial drums and trumpets and tubas The Dalai Lama is at his telescope. Three thousand PLA soldiers march along the shepherds's trail.  They march behind huge, red banners of Mao Tse-tu and Chu-te. This time, the soldiers do look like monsters.  Their fac are grey - coated with Tibetan dust.  Their peaked hats l vaguely like horns, their tattered, khaki uniforms like rough hide. Monks line the trail, whipping at the soldiers with their long, maroon robes.  Women and children spit at the Chine clap at them, hoping to chase this evil away.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, THE POTALA DAY

text: The Prime Ministers, Lukhangwa and Lobsang Tashi, submit their resignations to His Holiness. The boy takes the roll of parchment from them.
I am so sorry.
It must be done. We can no longer meet with the Chinese, they refuse us.
We hear the sounds of those Chinese tubas and trumpets. We hear trucks.
I accept your resignations.
Have you chosen your new Prime Ministers, Holiness?
There will be no new Prime Ministers.
You will face great difficulties, Holiness.
The boy affixes his small piece of parchment to the docum and makes a mark on it.
They have taken away our silence.

The Dalai Lama, with much pomp and ceremony, walks down a white carpet and steps into a coracle. The entourage includes:  the Lord Chamberlain, the Kashag His Holiness's Mother and youngest Brother, tutors and attendants. A hundred monks stand, chanting, on the far bank.

The Fourteenth Dalai Lama rides in a Chinese jeep.  Dust surrounds him.  A yellow silk umbrella shades him. We see that a road is under construction - a road into Lhasa. The first road in Tibet.  The Dalai Llama is trave in the opposite direction.  He is leaving his country, traveling on rugged, flattened earth.
The way is tougher here - the Dalai Lama is on mule back.

head_text.subj: EXT. CHINESE BORDER TOWN, SHINGANG DAY

text: This is a different land.  There are rice paddies and wat buffalo.  The altitude and barrenness of Tibet have been replaced by greener pastures, jagged mountaintops and Chinese natives.
Tenzin Gyatso gets his ride in an airplane - an antique. is bumpy and noisy.  He sits on an un-upholstered, steel frame.
The Dalai Lama travels by train.

The train pulls into the station. There are hundreds of people awaiting the arrival of the Dalai Lama - hundreds of "China pictorial", red-cheeked, Chinese communists;  men, women and children, waving litt red flags. Tenzin Gyatso steps off the train and there is a roar of approval.   Song breaks out - the People's Republic Natio Anthem. The young man is overwhelmed. We begin to sense that something is wrong, something is artificial.  The people's presence is demanded here today This is a forced display of regard.

head_text.subj: INT. GREAT HALL OF THE PEOPLE DAY

text: The Dalai Lama, and his retinue sit in this Great Hall, decorated with a portrait of Chairman Mao. The Great Helmsman himself is speaking. Mao Tse Tung's presence is charismatic.  His delivery is powerful - simple, yet firm.  He is spellbinding.
The mission of China is to bring progress to Tibet.  Develop its natural resources.  Help its people develop democracy. We welcome you, Tibet, back to the Motherland!

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S ROOM, CHINESE GUEST HOUSE NIGHT

text: Tenzin Gyatso snoops around this room.  He opens drawers, cabinets, just as a child would.  He finds odd little pie of ceramics, pens, paper. He moves to the bathroom, runs a bath.  Hot water. Electricity.  This is the modern world.

The Dalai Lama sits beside Chairman Mao as a horde of photographers flash bulbs in their faces.  Mao offers His Holiness a plate of Chinese delicacies. We notice that Mao's clothes are shabby and old. (His sui is always a shade lighter than everyone else's grey-drab) His cuffs are frayed, his collar is worn.  But, his shoes are beautifully polished. He has exquisite, delicate hands and his skin is shinny. Later, Chairman Mao and the Dalai Lama sit across from on another. Tenzin Gyatso takes notes as Mao speaks.
I am so glad that Tibet has come back to the Motherland.
Tenzin Gyatso quietly sips his tea.
You must inform me at once if any of our people abuse the Tibetans trust and good nature.
I have great hopes for the future of our co-operation.

It is too early to implement all the clauses of the Seventeen Point Agreement.  We will establish a Preparatory Committee for the Autonomous Region of Tibet.  The pace of reform must meet with the desires of the Tibetan people. Changes must be made slowly, as you, yourself, judge necessary.
Mao speaks and moves very slowly.  He pants and wheezes. appears to be sick.  Tenzin Gyatso takes notes.

I am happy to hear you say this, Chairman Mao.  I have created a reform committee to investigate grievances and we have abolished Inherited Tax, and forgiven all money owed the Government by people who are unable to pay.

Good. Very good. Tibet is a great country.  A a wonderful history.  Long ago, you even conquered part of China. But now you have fallen behind and we want to help you.  In twenty years time you could be ahead of us. Then it will be your turn to help China.
Tenzin Gyatso writes in his notebook.
You know, I have great respect for your Lord Buddha.  He was anti-caste. Anti-corruption.  Anti-exploitation. For some, politics and religion can mix.
For me, I think such a mix is crucial.
Have a sweet. Made in my home province.  The kind my mother used to make.
The Dalai Lama accepts.
Tenzin Gyatso does physical exercise with a few Chinese Bodyguards.
Tenzin Gyatso studies with Ling Rinpoche. The Lord Chamberlain sits with them.

"If moral discipline is learned from the beginning, one possesses the root for achieving higher rebirth.  A staircase for achieving liberation.  An antidote eliminating misery and sorrow.  Without discipline there is no method."
Pause.

I am thinking of becoming a Communist Party Member. I like what I see of Marxism.  It is based on equality and justice for all. I believe Chairman Mao wishes the best for our people.  Our path must be non-violence.  Co-operation.
The Lord Chamberlain simply looks at the young man.  He h nothing to say.
There is a knock and Tenzin Gyatso is led into the room. Mao is at his desk, working late, smoking heavily.
Ah, Dalai Lama, thank you for coming so late.
I leave tomorrow.
Yes, I am aware.  How has your time in China been?
Tenzin Gyatso sits. He takes out his book and pen, ready take notes.
I have been greatly impressed by your accomplishments.  Industrial progress.  Great efficiency. Your people are capable and courteous.

You have a lot to learn about organization.  How to draw out people's opinions.  How to make key decisions.  Train your young Tibetans.  When I make contact with you, I want to reach you through a Tibetan.
Always.
Tenzin Gyatso records Mao's words.

Your attitude is good, you know. I understand you well. But you need to learn this: religion is poison. It undermines the race and it retards the progress of the people.  Tibet has been poisoned by religion.
The boy cannot look up.  He is in shock.  We see the last words he writes: "Religion is poison."
Well, let me walk you to your car.

Tenzin Gyatso slowly gets to his feet.  We must see on hi face that he realizes it has all been lies.  All the kind words and promises, it must all be lies. He is unable to raise his face to Mao's.  All he sees bef him are those shinny shoes, those exquisitely shaped, glistening hands.
Outside this building, a black car is waiting.  It is bitterly cold. Mao - wearing no hat, no coat, and coughing - opens the d for the boy. The Dalai Lama shakes the man's hand.
Take care of your health.
Tenzin Gyatso gets into the car and Mao slams the door.
As the car drives away, Tenzin Gyatso turns to see the Chairman, still standing in the cold, still waving goodby Then, Tenzin Gyatso looks straight ahead and says:
He will betray us.
The view pulls back. The Lord Chamberlain sits beside the young man.
Did you ever doubt it?
I had relinquished doubt.

head_text.subj: EXT. TENZIN GYATSO'S HOUSE IN AMDO DAY

text: The Dalai Lama and members of his retinue stand in front his old house in the village of Taktser, Amdo Province. The young man smiles as he enters the courtyard.  He paus to look at the prayer flag, flapping in the breeze. He opens the front door.
A family of relatives inhabits the house.  They bow to Hi Holiness as the young man makes his way to the kitchen.

Tenzin Gyatso steps into the kitchen - he might have to b his head under the low ceiling.  He laughs his wonderful laugh. Immediately, a woman approaches with a cup of tea. But the hand of a Chinese official reaches out, takes the tea and returns it to her.  It is not permitted. The woman looks confused.  Tenzin Gyatso is humiliated.
A group has gathered outside the house. Tenzin Gyatso goes toward them as they prostrate.  When t have finished, he reaches out his hands to take theirs. He says to one old woman:
Are you happy?
The OLD WOMAN says, with tears in her eyes:
I am very happy and prosperous under the guidance of the Chinese Communist Party and chairman Mao Tse Tung.

It is a horrifying announcement. The Dalai Lama touches her head.  She weeps and clutches hands. The young man looks up, over her head, to Kyeri, the protectress mountain of this small village. We hear loudspeakers, blaring, in the background - trumpeting propaganda about Chairman Mao and the People's Liberation Army. Tibetan horns blow.  It sounds like a warning. CLOSE on a newspaper.  It is a Chinese newspaper and the picture on the front page shows a row of severed, Tibetan heads.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS DAY

text: Tenzin Gyatso puts the paper down.  He removes his glasse and turns to his advisor - the grand Lord Chamberlain.
I ask them to stop, to lay down their guns.
The Khamba's gun is his most prized possession.  I admire them so. They face a modern, well equipped army, and still, they fight.
The Dalai Lama rubs his face with his hands.
Land reform is underway in Amdo.  The large estates are being confiscated and redistributed. Landlords are being punished.
A beggar can be called a landlord if he disapproves of the Chinese.
The men are silent.  We hear the constant sound of trucks and cars. The Lord Chamberlain is notably pausing.
I have always asked for plain information.  Just the truth.

The Communists put their guns in the hands of the Khamba children and force the child to kill the parent. They have dropped bombs on the monastery of Lithang in Kham.  It has been destroyed. Women and children, trying to escape from the fighting, have been shot with machine guns, fired from airplanes.
Again, silence.
The pursuit of non-violence. Very difficult.
Non-violence means co-operation when it is possible.  Resistance, when it is not.

His Holiness walks to the terrace.  He aims the telescope Below him he sees a new Lhasa - a Lhasa full of trucks an Chinese soldiers.  A traffic island stands in the center an intersection.  The town walls are white-washed.  The political posters are gone.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, THE NORBULINKA DAY

text: A small group sits waiting on red velvet chairs: the Dala Lama, the Lord Chamberlain and the Kashag. General Chiang enters the room. He finds a chair and pour himself a cup of tea.  We cannot help but notice - he is armed.
We have decided that no drastic changes will take place in Tibet for six years. This should make you happy.
Silence.
It seems a revolt has broken out in the east. We have decided that the Tibetan army must be used against the Khamba guerrillas.
The General sips. The Dalai Lama answers.
I will not approve it.
The General looks up, surprised.  It took a great deal of courage for the young man to answer back, so determinedly
You have bombed on peaceful people.
We must deal with these reactionaries!
No.  We are peace loving people. I am afraid we cannot trust you.
The General sputters:
We are here to heal the people of Tibet.  You need reform. You have no sense of what is good for your people. We are here to liberate you!
Now, the boy finds his voice.
I burn here, but I am not suppose to let the smoke show.  Yes, we need reform.  The monasteries. Communications.  Schools.  But we want change for Tibet, as Tibet needs it, not for China.
The General starts to speak but Tenzin Gyatso keeps talki
Buddha is our physician, General, he will heal us.  Comapssion and enlightnement will set us free. You can not liberate me I can only liberate myself.
The General leaves the room.
They will take Lhasa next.
The people will not allow it.
The Nechung Oracle is in full swing.  It is an especially vivid and violent spin he is in.  The headdress whips thi way and that, and finally he says:
Where there is no crossing a big river, no fords, no shallows, where the only hope is a boat, and there is no boat... I will put a boat, Kundun. The wish-Fulfilling Jewel will shine from the West.
It is a strange and confusing prophecy.
A few random views of the Norbulinka: The wandering deer and peacocks.  The fish pond and its inhabitants. Over these pictures we hear words:
"I rejoice in the Awakening of the Buddhas, and also in the spiritual levels of their Sons."
The projection room.  The full sheep pen.  The parents's home.
"And with gladness I rejoice in the ocean of virtue from developing an awakening mind that wishes all beings to be happy..."
The Yellow Wall.  The Dalai Lama's red room.
"As well as in the deeds that bring them benefit.
And now, we hear the voices of a great many people, reciting:
"With folded hands I beseech the Buddhas of all directions. To shine the lamp of Dharma For all bewildered in the gloom of misery."

In the midst of war, there is beauty. The Dalai Lama performs the Kalachakra ceremony. It is a beautiful, ornate, colorful ceremony.  A prayer f world peace. Tenzin Gyatso sits on a platform of cushions, above the heads of the abbots and lamas and tutors, above the heads of the Tibetan noblemen, and nomads and Khambas and pesants from all corners of the land who attend the ceremony.
"With folded hands I beseech the Conquerors who wish to pass away, to please remain for countless aeons And not to leave the world in darkness."

The Dalai Lama proceeds with the ceremony.  He handles an blesses sacred objects, he lifts his bell and dorge. Rice is passed among the people.  Rice is thrown. A Tibetan chant is sung. Beside His Holiness is a large, yellow silk pagoda. The view moves inside the pagoda as the chanting continue
We see a mandala - a beautiful, intricate, sand-painting. The home of Kalachakra.
"Thus by the virtue collected Through all that I have done, May the pain of every living creature be completely cleared away."

The whole screen becomes this mandala as the chanting an cymbals and deep resonating sounds of the song continue a then, a hand comes into the mandala and begins to sweep i up. Pull back to see that the hand belongs to Tenzin Gyatso. Tenzin Gyatso collects the ground particles of Tibetan quartz and rock.  He destroys the painstakingly lovely sa painting. The chanting becomes louder and louder and it mixes with sound of the river.
Tenzin Gyatso pours the sand into the river. We watch the river take color and the mandala floats away This view is overlapped by one of extreme horror.

The lovely Norbulinka garden, the park where opera pagean and Kalachakra ceremonies take place, is now, a killing field. Hundreds of dead, slaughtered monks, lie on the blood- drenched ground, under the peach and pear trees.  Chinese soldiers move amongst the monks, turning over the dead bodies, searching those silent faces.  The Solder we see carrying a photo of His Holiness.  They are searching for the Dalai Lama. It is a nightmare. We hear crying. DREAM SEQUENCE ENDS. Tenzin Gyatso wakes up.  Shaking, crying, he is alone, in the dark.  He can barely catch his breath. The screen goes black. CLOSE on an invitation: His Holiness, the Dalai Lama of Tibet, is invited to attend a Dance Recital at the newly erected, Great Hall of the Liberation Army. 10 March, 1959.
A last view of the great monastery. We hear the sound of thousands of Tibetan women shouting;
Chinese, GO! Chinese, GO! Chinese, GO!

head_text.subj: EXT. DALAI LAMA'S RESIDENCE, NORBULINKA DAY

text: Tenzin Gyatso steps outside.  The shouting grows louder:
Chinese, GO! Chinese, GO! Chinese, GO!

The young man looks around at the peaceful premises.  Peo we know - uembers of the Kashag, attendants, tutors, the Dalai Lama's Mother, sweepers - appear in the garden, one one, all listening to the sounds of a uob gathering outsi the walls of the Norbulinka.
Chinese, GO! Chinese, GO! Chinese, GO!

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS, NORBULINKA DAY

text: A meeting is in progress.
The crowd will not disperse until you give your assurance that you will not attend the Chinese festivities. Many who have been invited to dine with the Chinese do not return home.
I will not go.
I will alert the Chinese delegation. You know, I would never have let you go alone, Kundun.

The Dalai Lama enters his Mother's home. It is very guiet here.  The young man looks at the family photographs on the blue walls, the needlework on the tabl the seven copper bowls in front of the statue of Buddha.
Did you come to tell me we are leaving Lhasa?
The boy fills the seven bowls with water.  His Mother lig the butter lamps.
Do you think I must?
You decide.
He says, softly:
Tibet has never been part of China.  We are different races. We are different cultures. We need change, we know that. But we could do it alone. We were just about to do it alone.
The young man fills the last bowl with water.
I am afraid I will go. Far, far away.
The Lord Chamberlain approaches the Dalai Lama as he leav his Mother's house.
We are now accused of aiding the rebels.  The Chinese said we can expect drastic measures to be taken to crush this revolt.
Arrange for me to speak to the people's leaders.
The Lord Chamberlain hurries away.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS DUSK

text: A last meeting in session. The Kashag is present, as are fifty leaders of the opposition - rough, tired men.
I fear that there will be great bloodshed if you cannot convince the people to disperse and go home. I am safe.

Holiness, the Chinese tried to entice you to their garrison with out protection of bodyguard. Even now, they urge you to come to them for safety. They are bringing more troops and guns and artillery into Lhasa. There are three airplanes waiting outside Lhasa. What do they wait for?  They are planning to kill the Dalai Lama.  Don't you see?

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS NIGHT

text: The Dalai Lama consults the Nechung Oracle.  Alone. The Oracle whispers:
Stay.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS NIGHT

text: It is late at night.  The boy is alone.  He sits in front his altar - meditating.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS NIGHT

text: The Nechung Oracle is brought in.  The monk quiets himsel and readies himself for the trance. The Dalai Lama waits.  Again, alone. Slowly, the trance comes on, the heavy headdress is place on the monk's head, the attendants leave the room and the the Oracle speaks.
Stay.  I tell you to stay.
The Lord Chamberlain hurries up the stairs. Tenzin Gyatso steps forward, out of the shadows.
The Chinese are planning to attack the crowd and shell the Norbulinka. You are asked to indicate on a map where you will be so that the artillery men will not mistakenly aim at you.
The Dalai Lama walks down the outdoor stairs.
Tell them I will be here. With my people. Right here.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS DAY

text: The young man is studying with Ling Rinpoche. Books of scripture are stacked in front of him. Suddenly, there is a tremendous, loud explosion, and then another. Tenzin Gyatso gets up and runs to the window he looked ou of the day of the earthquake.
There is shouting and chaos.  The Chinese have begun shelling the Norbulinka.  The north wall and the grounds directly in front of it are on fire.

This time the Oracle is in the room first.  He is surroun by his attendants and the members of the Kashag, the Lord Chamberlain, Ling Rinpoche and various tutors and lamas. The tension is thick.  Finally, the Dalai Lama enters. Tenzin Gyatso sits.  He waits.  The trance begins, the headdress is set upon the medium's head and the Oracle begins to dance, and then, he begins to shout:
Go!  Go!  Tonight!
The Oracle staggers forward, snatches up some paper and a pen and begins to draw a map, a route, out of Lhasa.  He keeps repeating:
Go!  Tonight!  Go!

CLOSE on the map - drawn with a shaking, sweating hand. We see mountains, and a pass, and the names of towns alon the way. Tenzin Gyatso rises and goes to the Oracle.  He looks dow at the map.  The Oracle hands the Dalai Lama the map and faints as his frightened attendants rush to loosen the st of the headdress before the poor man chokes.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS DUSK

text: The boy sits at the table, writing.  We can hear the crow shouting, outside the Norbulinka walls.  We see just a fe words of the letter: Please do not resist. Take refuge on the far side of the river.
Attendants pack, quietly and quickly.

The chapel of Mahakala. We are reminded of secret, sacred moments, from long ago. Tenzin Gyatso opens the heavy, creaking door.  The Dalai Lama is in disguise.  He is wearing the clothes of a Kham guerrilla - dark, woolen chuba and tall black boots. Monks sit on the floor, chanting.  One monk stands by a large urn, ladling out butter for the lamps. Tenzin Gyatso goes to the front of the room. A monk begins to play the cymbals. Another puts the Tibetan horn to his lips and blows a long, mournful note. The Dalai Lama lays a white silk scarf - a kata - over th shoulders of this imposing statue. Then, he sits for a moment. In the weak light, in the black room, Tenzin Gyatso is lo among the other praying monks.
The Dalai Lama walks down the hall.  He says to a sweeper
Dim the lights.
and then he bow bends down, to pat a dog.

head_text.subj: INT. DALAI LAMA'S PRIVATE ROOMS NIGHT

text: Tenzin Gyatso rolls the thangka of Penden Lhamo and slide it into its ancient container. The young man places the scroll over one shoulder.

head_text.subj: INT. ENTRANCE OF RESIDENCE, NORBULINKA NIGHT

text: CLOSE on the little cabinet in the corner of the entrance hall. Tenzin Gyatso's hands open the doors. The young man pulls open the drawer which contains the fa teeth. Tenzin Gyatso pulls a rolled kata from his coat.  He tuck the lead soldier of an Indian Ghurka into the center of t scarf.  He places the bundle in the drawer. Then, he adds something.  A sweet.  The kind his Mother makes. He closes the drawer, and locks it. He hides the key, again, behind the small, unobtrusive cabinet.
With a soldier on either side of him, the Dalai Lama descends the staircase. The Soldiers start to lead him away, but he pauses.
Wait.
The young man leaves them.
He walks to the far side of this white building.
I see a safe journey.
The boy returns to the front steps.
I see a safe return.
The soldiers wait.
Now.  I am ready.
Tenzin Gyatso places the scroll over one shoulder.  A soldier lays a rifle over the other one.
The three men walk quietly through the empty gardens.  We hear the sounds of the crowd grow louder.
The soldiers pause, look to His Holiness.  Tenzin Gyatso removes his glasses, puts them in his bag, then nods - an the soldiers open the gate.
Move aside, tour of inspection, move aside.

Of course, we see only a fraction of the crowd - angry me and women. A man steps beside His Holiness. Tenzin Gyatso looks up - face to face. It is the Khamba bodyguard, the monk who guarded him so m times.  The man with the horrible face.
Move aside, let us through. Move aside!

The Dalai Lama is between the soldiers, shouldering his o gun.  The Bodyguard falls in behind. The little group makes its way through the crowd. EXT.  TRIBUTARY OF ThE KYICHU RIVER  NIGHT In the same place where the little Tenzin Gyatso tentativ tested one rock, the escape party crosses on the slippery stepping stones.
The small party makes its way across a bit of countryside People are camped here - Khambas, farmers, nomads.  The Dalai Lama crosses to safety - unnoticed.

Coracles await. The Dalai Lama climbs in, the Lord Chmaberlian sits besid him.  The soldiers push off. The Khamba Bodyguard stands the bank, alone. Every splash of the oars sounds like it could wake the de Tenzin Gyatso looks back.  He puts on his glasses. He sees camp fires and the glow of torches.  He hears ech voices. He looks up.  He sees the stars and the moon and that incomparable Tibetan sky. He looks forward. He sees mountains.
I have always loved mountains.
He is handed a steaming cup of tea. And then, a cloud passes over the moon.

On horse back, the party makes its way up a mountain pass There are more members now - Tenzin Gyatso has joined tho who left ahead of him - members of the Kashag, tutors, hi Mother, his Brother. It is tough going.  The ground seems like quick sand with every step a struggle.  When the horses have disappeared from sight, a sand storm arises, wiping away their tracks
The party passes above an encampment of Chinese soldiers. They are not seen.
The party travels through the emptiness.

"Right will be victorious."

The Dalai Lama sits before a low table set up on this desolate border. A document is before him.
I repudiate the Seventeen Point Agreement
With a slap of the State Seal of Tibet, this is done. The Lord Chamberlain removes this document and replaces i with another.
I constitute the Government of Tibet, the only legal authority in the land.
The seal comes down hard once more.  It is done.

A sick and tired Tenzin Gyatso makes the last leg of his trip on the back of a black yak. Before him, through the light rain, we see a small bamboo arch erected in the middle of nowhere.
